title: Honoring Trey Reed & Continuing the Fight for Justice.
description:
Honoring Trey Reed & Continuing the Fight for Justice.
___________________________________________
We are coming together to raise funds for a permanent headstone for Trey Reed—a son, a brother, a friend, and a life taken too soon. Trey's memory with dignity, love, and respect.
But this is more than just about a headstone. Trey's life and death represent the urgent need to keep fighting for justice. Every contribution helps us not only cover the costs of his headstone but also support ongoing organizing efforts: protests, awareness campaigns, and community action to make sure his story is never forgotten and that no other family has to endure this pain.
Your donation will:
Provide Trey with a beautiful headstone to honor his legacy.
Support the continued fight for justice in his name.
Help cover the cost of organizing protests, community outreach, and advocacy.
Trey Reed's life mattered.
His story matters.
Together, we can honor him properly and carry his spirit forward in the struggle for justice.
Thank you for your love, your support, and your solidarity.
labels: People, Community, Happiness, Buzz cut

title: Support Velez Jiu Jitsu's New Home
description:
Velez Jiu Jitsu's home gym has been totaled in a fire overnight. No lives were lost, and we thank first responders for acting with such bravery.
This location was a second home for many of us. The memories we've made here will last forever. Together, we will rebuild what was lost and rise from the ashes stronger than ever.
The fund will be reserved for helping set up a new location.
labels: Logo, Symbol, Graphics, Emblem, Graphic design

title: Next Step Produce Disaster Relief
description:
My dear friends Heinz and Gabrielle would never ask for your help and are not the kind of people to hold a grudge, so instead of asking permission, I’ll seek the forgiveness they would never withhold.
Their farm in Newburg, MD suffered a tragic loss on Wednesday, Oct 1, 2025.
Around 10 pm, Gabrielle noticed their 75x100 grain house was on fire. Despite efforts by firefighters from three different counties, the flames proved to be too much. Hundreds of thousands of dollars in product, numerous grain cleaning, sorting, heating, drying and grinding machinery were destroyed in the fire by early morning. While insurance will cover the cost of certain things, it won’t meet the replacement value on anything. Their once bustling grain mill is no more and the grain cultivated and grown for decades has vanished with the smoke. I am crushed for this passionate, hardworking, and humble family and am asking you to assist them in any way possible.
Next Step Produce was always ahead of its time cultivating wholesome, nutritious morganic (‘more than organic’) grains, fruits, vegetables, spices, and more for over 25 years.
They have been supplying some of DC and Baltimore's finest restaurants, bakeries, and also used to be a feature at DC’s DuPont farmers market pre-Covid. After Covid, Heinz pushed full steam ahead with grain production, including varieties of rice, wheat, and beans. Every single machine used towards that endeavor has been lost to the fire. Grain growers from all over the East Coast would source Heinz and his setup to process their own grains. On top of that, decades of work and germination testing, along with all the seeds saved, were also consumed in the fire.
This loss is devastating, to say the least.
Anything, including an encouraging word or gesture, would be of great help.
I thank you for reading this and I appreciate all the thoughts and prayers directed towards the Thomet family during this time.
For more information about their farm, visit:
www.nextstepproduce.com
https://www.facebook.com/nextstepproduce/
labels: Tableware, Drinkware, Stemware, Alcoholic drink, Barware

title: Re-Animate Old Seattle's New Favorite Music Shop
description:
Hey Seattle, it’s been too long. We, the former employees of The Trading Musician, are starting a brand new music shop in the U District - just three blocks from the old place, right across from Cowen Park. We’re excited to see you all again at Re-Animated Music, and we want to share the story and the mission statement with you.
When the old place shut down last year it left a massive crater in our music scene. Many of us grew up going there, met bandmates and best friends, bought our first and tenth and favorite guitars, and we know that many of you did too. We were able to help everyone from local folks just starting out to high profile touring bands. We always took pride in being accessible, affordable and fair - but more than that it was a place to see your friends, talk about music, learn about weird gear and get a pack of strings or a pair of drum sticks. We were a refreshing alternative to the big corporate hellscape of a music store up the street.
We all tried working and shopping at other places, but the DIY ethos just wasn’t there, and we didn’t feel they shared our values of how a music shop should be run. These core principles are imperative to what we want our new shop to be:
Keeping instruments available to everyone without a huge paywall or price point that bars the average musician from obtaining vintage equipment. Continuing to serve the community as a resource for information and education. Hosting workshops and empowering you with the knowledge to properly use and maintain your gear. Stocking an extensive library of parts, and providing the services you need to make your instruments the best they can be. Making sure that everything we sell is set up to our standard of playability regardless of price. At its core, we want this new store to be an inspiring place that has the things you need and the off-the-beaten-path treasures you didn’t know you wanted. We want the focus to be on helping our peers - not getting rich.
It became clear that if we wanted to stay in the industry, we needed to start a place of our own. After months of searching, we found the perfect location earlier this year, and we’ve been working to get it ready ever since. The people we meet walking by every day, the musicians we talk to at shows, and the folks that pull over just to look inside all seem really excited for what’s coming.
Our hope was to be open for business back in June but we encountered some massive setbacks with the city. Our renovation and build-out quickly ballooned to double the initial cost and tripled the timeline to open. We heard the same story from all our friends who are contractors, tradespeople, business owners - that this city has no interest in making it easy for small businesses to start up or stay afloat. There are endless and ever-changing hoops to jump through, and every license and permit along the way is expensive. Even seemingly minor regulations can have huge, prohibitively costly implications and these things can, and have, bankrupted businesses before they even get off the ground. Not a problem if you’re a massive corporation or tech company, but the very same hundreds of thousands of dollars are expected of ordinary people, DIYers and independent artists. Since there is no system in place to help lessen that burden, what ends up happening is exactly what you’d expect: the big companies flourish while the mom-and-pops go out of business if they ever exist in the first place.
This is not an accident. Cool alternative businesses usually don’t present a big economic gain for the city, so there’s very little incentive for them to make it work. It’s a calculated effort to prioritize profit over people and community. This is why we have fewer and fewer shops like the one we aim to build. The odds are increasingly stacked against us.
As local musicians, we know people need this kind of place. Places to be together and learn from each other. Places to invent new sounds and fix broken instruments, where everyone involved knows it’s about bringing the music to life - not getting rich. It’s up to us to take care of each other and support the few spots where we can still encounter vibrant interactive art.
We're committed to making it happen. We are here putting in the work, and we are so close to being ready to share this with you, but the costs so far have been pretty staggering. None of us had startup money and after the unexpected and expensive remodels the city required (and the months of rent it took to complete them), we are facing some super intimidating loans. Your donations will be immensely helpful in recouping some of our debt and covering those extensive building costs while we get started. We are endlessly grateful for whatever you can contribute, and we hope that you’ll come hang out with us when we open the doors - we’re shooting for Halloween.
P.S. There are plenty of other ways to help out aside from donating. Please get in touch with us if you have used gear you’d like to sell or donate. We could really use some rugs and carpet - and probably more stuff we’ll think of later. We want to hear from you, even just to talk. There's an option to contact us on this page, or we're on Instagram @reanimatedmusic.
labels: Bone, Skeleton, Skull, Graphics, Graphic design

title: DQ Sisters: Always giving, now needing our help.
description:
They’ve Always Been There for Us…Now Let’s Be There for Them.
I’ve worked at the Dairy Queen in Medford, NY for years, and I can say without hesitation that our “DQ Sisters” — Michelle and Pat — are more than just owners. They are the heart of this place, and for so many of us, they’ve become family.
I’ve seen it with my own eyes: they’ve stepped in like surrogate mothers when life gets tough. They’ve pulled off Christmas miracles for employees’ kids, quietly paid for funerals, celebrated graduations, and lifted us up through struggles big and small. When one of our team members was battling cancer, they organized a fundraiser to help cover costs. They’ve handed employees money out of their own pockets when someone couldn’t make rent or cover an emergency expense.
The DQ Sisters have also built this Dairy Queen into a true second chance company. They hire people others might overlook — those with disabilities, people rebuilding after addiction, and even folks with felony records who just needed someone to believe in them. For many of us, this place was the only door that opened when every other one was shut. Working here has never just been a job — it’s been a safe, stable, and caring home because of Michelle and Pat.
Now, they’re facing something that could take it all away.
Back in 2020, the DQ Sisters were blindsided with a class action lawsuit over a technicality in how often “manual workers” are paid under New York law. They always followed the state’s guidance, worked through ADP payroll, and made sure every cent of our paychecks was right. But the lawyers wouldn’t back down.
Under immense pressure, Michelle and Pat were forced to settle for $450,000 — more than $300,000 of which went straight to attorney’s fees. The rest will be divided among over 200 employees in the class action (most of whom had no idea this lawsuit even existed).
The most heartbreaking part? The sisters fought to change the law so other small businesses wouldn’t suffer the same fate — and they actually succeeded. But their victory came too late to save themselves.
This settlement has left them devastated. I’ve watched them give their lives to keep this Dairy Queen running for us and our community. And now, unless we rally around them, we could lose it all.
That’s why I’m asking — as a friend, an employee, and someone who loves these women like family — for your help. Every donation will go directly toward helping Michelle and Pat cover this crushing settlement and keep our Dairy Queen open.
If you’ve ever been touched by their generosity, enjoyed a cone or a Blizzard made with love, or simply believe in standing up for good people in a bad situation, please donate if you can and share this far and wide.
Let’s keep the lights on, the soft-serve flowing, and the spirit of the DQ Sisters alive in Medford.

description:

title: Rebuild a family business damaged by fire.
description:
Hi,
I'm Haley, and my husband, Alec, and his business partner (and close friend), David, opened their new business a week and a half ago. Their grand opening was meant to be on October 11th of this year. Alec and David have poured all their energy and passion into the last seven months, making this building a reality for their dreams. Yesterday evening, a neighboring business caught on fire, and the flames impacted Alec and David's new shop. They will no longer be able to open their business, with what wasn't damaged by fire damaged by water-- including very many sentimental art pieces that the two painted. With the current state of the building, our families are left without direction on where to go next. Alec and David are without means to continue working at this time and are hopeful they will be able to reopen soon.
Alec and David are some of the kindest, most generous people I have ever known. While I may not have an objective perspective, I have witnessed Alec go out of his way time and time again to help his community and the people he loves, even at an inconvenience to himself. David and his wife, Alisun, have always opened the doors of their home to any of their friends who needed a place to stay or a meal on a holiday.
It is devastating to our families as we have been overjoyed to see their life's work come to fruition. We never expected to have to ask for help in this way, and appreciate any kind words or support.
labels: Motor vehicle, Automotive lighting, Car, Automotive Exterior, Automotive Parking Light

title: Urgent Help Needed to Keep Our Business Open
description:
Hi everyone,
We don’t usually ask for help, and it took a lot for us to finally do so.. but we’re being pushed to a difficult point. Due to the current economic situation, we’ve fallen behind on some bills. Our rent, which is close to $9,000 a month, has put a really heavy strain on our finances as a small business.
We are now being asked to pay $32,741.69 in past-due bills that we’ve been doing our best to keep up with. We have until Friday, October 10th, to pay or we will have to close our doors.
Any help or support means the world to us. Thank you all so much for standing by us through everything.
labels: Restaurant, Houseplant, Retail

title: Help Mayson Ali Al-Tahrawi Provide for Her Children
description:
My name is Mayson Ali Al-Tahrawi. I am a mother of six children – four boys and two girls – living in Gaza, where life has turned into a daily struggle for survival.
Since the start of this brutal and bloody war, my children and I have been living through unimaginable fear and suffering. The continuous attacks, the destruction all around us, and the endless nights of terror have left deep scars on our hearts. But what makes survival even harder is the ongoing siege that has cut us off from the most basic necessities of life.
Food is scarce, and what little is available comes at prices we cannot afford. Hygiene items, clean water, clothes, and even the simplest household needs have become almost impossible to find. My children often go to bed hungry, and as a mother, it is unbearable to see their small faces looking at me for comfort when I have so little to give.
The blockade has not only destroyed our economy but also our ability to live with dignity. Every day feels like a fight against time — against hunger, cold, and fear. We are trying to survive, but survival is impossible without help.
I am reaching out to you, with all the strength and hope I have left, asking for your support. Your donations can help me provide food for my children, hygiene supplies to keep them healthy, clothes to keep them warm, and other essentials to carry us through these desperate times.
I know the world is full of needs and challenges, but here in Gaza, our situation is critical beyond words. Even the smallest act of kindness can mean the world to us. Your generosity is not just a donation — it is a lifeline.
From my heart to yours, thank you for reading, for caring, and for standing with us in our darkest hours. May you be blessed for every act of compassion you show
labels: Rubble, geological phenomenon, Bedrock, Happiness, Building material

title: Help Us Grow Our Transport Business
description:
Help Us Grow: Support Our Transportation Business
Two Years Strong – Let’s Drive into the Future Together!
Hello, my name is Gary Scott, and I’m the proud founder of MWP TRANSPORTATION LLC, a locally owned transportation company that has been serving Illinois and Indiana for the past two years. We provide reliable, on-time, and community-focused transportation services for everything from personal rides to freight logistics.
What started as one vehicle and a dream has grown into a small but mighty operation that serves dozens of customers every week. We’ve built trust, delivered consistently, and kept our wheels turning through all challenges. Now, we’re ready to expand—but we need your help to take the next big step.
Why We're Raising Funds
We’re seeking to raise $145,000 to help us grow and meet the increasing demand for safe, affordable, and dependable transportation services in our area.
Here’s exactly what your donation will support:
Additional Vehicle Purchase – To increase capacity and reduce wait times
Vehicle Maintenance and Upgrades – Keeping our current fleet safe and efficient
Booking System Improvements – Making it easier for customers to schedule rides or shipments
Hiring and Training New Drivers – Creating job opportunities in our community
What Makes Us Different
✅ Locally owned and operated
✅ Serving seniors, students, working families & small businesses
✅ Affordable rates with a focus on reliability and safety
✅ Strong customer base and 5-star service track record
We’ve operated with minimal outside funding up until now, reinvesting every dollar back into the business. With your help, we can scale responsibly, meet growing demand, and create even more impact in our community.
How You Can Help
Donate – Every dollar helps! No amount is too small.
Share – Spread the word with friends, family, and your network.
Gratitude and Transparency
We believe in transparency and will share regular updates here on how your contributions are being used. This business is more than transportation—it's a lifeline for many in our community, and we’re deeply grateful for any support.
Let’s move forward—together.
Thank you for riding with us.
labels: Motorcycle, Logo, Fuel tank, Shock absorber, Motorcycling

title: Support Enrique's Dream Restaurant Opening
description:
Hello, my name is Enrique, Chef and Owner of Borinquen Lunch Box and now the new owner of the Clubhouse Restaurant at Aquia Harbour Borinquen Bar & Grill. It was a hard decision to run this GoFundMe to raise money for the restaurant. In the beginning, thanks to some very good friends that helped by investing in the restaurant with good startup capital. But as we began paying dues, like the security deposit and first month for the restaurant, applying for the permit, licenses, and insurances, we got a couple of small pieces of equipment. But mainly, we had to take some of the restaurant capital and put it in Borinquen Lunch Box to keep it running, especially to pay $4000.00 to repair the generator, something that took us by surprise.
So now we are facing a shortfall in capital to be able to open the restaurant on time by our deadline. We applied for a couple of capital loans but were denied because our restaurant is not in operation yet. They were all asking for a minimum of 6 months in operation and at least $250,000 in revenue. So I came to a hard decision to ask for help from all of you. If there is any way that you all can donate and help us open this restaurant, I will be very grateful. That will help us buy a new and needed commercial oven and eventually a new beer fridge for the bar. Enough to pay the new hires' training until we open the restaurant. Also, buy the startup inventory and provisions: food, beverage, and liquor.
We will appreciate any donations. I know some people like to stay anonymous, but please leave us your phone number or email to thank you .
GOD BLESS YOU!
Enrique & Mary
labels: Logo, Advertising, Palm trees

title: Keep Consorte Restaurant Open: Help Chef Miguel
description:
AYUDA para la recuperación De CHEF MIGUEL Y El Restaurante CONSORTE
En Junio 2025 el Chef Miguel sufrió una caída con la cual se fracturó un tobillo y se afectó severamente de su hombro. Tuvo que ser intervenido quirúrgicamente y tuvo que cerrar el negocio varias semanas para su recuperación. Ésto afectó severamente las finanzas y operaciones del negocio. Aún así sin estar completamente recuperado siguió trabajando y luchando día a día desde su silla de ruedas . Cuando algo así ocurre no solo se afecta Miguel sino se afectan empleados y todo lo que conlleva el negocio .
Consorte es un restaurante donde se disfruta de buena comida, música y buen servicio en un ambiente cálido y familiar.
Consorte Restaurant Ayuda a la comunidad con empleo local, estimula la economía y preservación Cultura Cubana.
Humildemente necesitamos su ayuda. La meta es $40k antes de OCTUBRE 8 que son los
costó debido para mantener el Restaurante abierto. Su Donación será Extremadamente Agradecidos. Sinceramente les pido de Corazón con Fe en Dios adelante!
Gracias por su Apoyo ! Team Consorte !
WE NEED YOUR HELP to keep CONSORTE RESTAURANT Opened!!!
In June 2025 Chef Miguel suffered a fall which fractured his ankle and his right shoulder. This incident let to emergency surgery to reconstruct Miguel’s ankle. We had to close the restaurant for severals weeks. Miguel even without being completely recupere kept working every day in his wheel chair. When something like this happens it not only affects Miguel, but also the business, the employees and everything that has to do with the Restaurant.
Consorte Restaurant is a restaurant where you have a great time, the food is delicious, great cuban drinks, service and a warm quality family place. We gladly help our community by bringing local jobs, boosting the economy with bringing authentic Cuban Culture food and flair to the upcoming town of Luquillo Plaza.
We humbly need your help. We need a miracle of 40K by OCTOBER 8. This is the cost owed to date to keep the Restaurant Open. Your donation will be extremely appreciated.
Sincerely, with open heart.
Team Consorte
labels: Customer, Cleanliness, Food truck

title: Save the Graber Olive House Before It’s Gone Forever
description:
Help Save the Graber Olive House – A 131-Year-Old Family Legacy
I’m Kelsey Graber, married to fourth generation, Robert Graber, into a 131-year-old family business named the Graber Olive House in Ontario, California. Our 131-year-old family business, the Graber Olive House, is in danger of being lost forever. As many of you know, the property is currently closed and now in the foreclosure process. Without immediate help, our community risks losing a piece of living history. For more than four generations, our family has poured our hearts and lives into this landmark, welcoming school tours, weddings, and family visits that have created countless memories for so many.
Even though foreclosure has begun, it is not yet final. With your support, we still have a chance to preserve the property and cover urgent expenses. Every donation will go directly toward utilities, loan payments, and essential operating costs needed to try to reopen its doors and prevent this one-of-a-kind site from being lost to development. We are at risk of losing this landmark in the coming months without support.
The Graber Olive House is more than just our family business, it is a living part of California’s history. On the grounds stand towering redwoods, a 250-year-old California Live Oak, and the original “Graber’s Firethorn” plant. The property is also home to the CC Graber House, olive trees, palm trees, and unique plants like the fragrant Watsonia marginata, which has been part of the site’s story for generations.
As long as we are able, we are committed to doing everything possible to continue preserving it for future generations.
Please consider donating and sharing to help us navigate this extremely difficult time and to give this historic landmark a fighting chance to survive.
Challenges we experienced and continue to face:
• COVID closures: Tours, events, and retail traffic—our lifeblood—dropped dramatically, wiping out critical operating revenue for an extended period.
• A poor crop season: Low to no yields, higher processing costs meant less product to sell, and thinner margins.
• A family buyout: To continue the family business, we took on additional obligations that became difficult to service once revenue fell.
• Rising costs: Insurance, utilities, materials, state wages, and maintenance for a 131 year-old property all climbed, compounding the strain.
• Partnership setback: A preservation partnership was halted when there was an appeal to our conditional use permit, leading the city to impose restrictive conditions that made it nearly impossible to operate fully as an event venue to cover costs in deferred maintenance on our property.
• Loss of Investors: Because of the city’s restrictive conditions, investor confidence has declined, forcing us once again to fight alone in search of someone who truly believes in preservation over quick profit.
We’re doing everything we can, but time is running out. Please donate or share to help us protect this irreplaceable piece of Ontario’s history. Please follow us on Facebook at Graber Olives for updates and news.
Thank you in advance for your donation, your support means the world to our family. Please help spread the word by sharing the news to your community. Sincerely, Kelsey Graber
labels: People, Smile, Photograph, Happiness, Face

title: Rebuilding La Paz Mexican Restaurant
description:
Dear friends and community members,
We are the Mendez Family, and we’ve proudly owned and operated LA PAZ Mexican Restaurant for 47 years. We consider El Segundo our home. Recently we faced an unexpected and devastating event: a car accident caused significant damage to our restaurant, leaving us struggling to continue our operations.
We are now facing an enormous financial strain. Insurance won’t kick in for at least three months. In the meantime, we are trying to support our staff and their families. We fully plan to rebuild and repair the restaurant. We cannot operate until our building is inspected for safety.
We work day to day to pay our staff and our greatest concern is supporting them and their families. 11 employees and their families are struggling right now while we remain closed. We are looking towards our community to help us bridge the gap to support our employees and keep our business afloat until we can reopen.
We are asking for your help to raise $60,000 which would cover one month of our operating costs. Nearly 40% of that goes towards our employees. We also have vendors that need to be paid, rent, and utilities that are due. These funds will go directly to these immediate expenses. Any contribution, big or small, will make a world of difference and will allow us to continue serving the community that we love.
We’ve proudly served the greater El Segundo community for 47 years and though we’ve faced hardships like Covid, recessions, and relocation, we’ve never faced a situation like this where we cannot operate in any capacity. We’ve always been able to find a way through, but we are running out of options. Please help us weather this storm by donating and/or sharing this page.
labels: Motor vehicle, Car, Automotive Tire, Automotive Exterior, Automotive lighting

title: 《追光者 PULSE HK》 育成計劃：一個屬於香港人的新聞平台，以專業態度為世界各地香港人提供24小時新聞資訊。
description:
《追光者 PULSE HK》眾籌成立計劃
《追光者 PULSE HK》是一個全新的香港人國際新聞平台，由兩大海外港媒英國《追新聞》與台灣《光傳媒》，聯同前《自由亞洲電台》粵語組主任、前《有線新聞》中國組主管胡力漢，以及前《蘋果日報》動新聞主管李家聰共同創立。新平台計劃在三個地方設有分社：台灣、英國、北美，為世界各地的香港人提供24小時新聞。
為何要眾籌？
我們的新聞平台屬於香港人，會以專業持平的態度報道新聞，為香港人發聲。惟我們背後並沒有金主或「大水喉」支持，要讓《追光者》成為黑暗中的燈塔，必須要靠大家的參與及貢獻。
眾籌用途？
我們計劃組成15至20人的專業團隊，成員都是流散世界各地的資深新聞人，希望藉着我們的豐富經驗及新聞觸覺，填補過去幾年香港新聞界因為無法看到的紅線而出現的黑洞。我們會專注影像報道，除每日半小時新聞，亦會製作「懶人包」影片；另會提供深入的中國調查報道。PULSE HK 將設「英語組」，以英語報道香港本地以及國際新聞，尤其專注於世界各地港人社群關心的社會時事。
為何是400萬？
要維持這個運作規模，我們預算每月開支最少要港幣50萬元，長遠我們打算透過讀者訂閱、廣告及 YouTube 收益做到收支平衡，但估計要6至8個月時間才能達成目標，因此我們希望眾籌港幣400萬元作為新平台的起動資金。
一個新聞平台，永遠不能單獨存在，它是一個有機之物，如何生存、成長，並非幾個人之事。這點光，能否成為一座照亮黑暗的燈塔，在充滿暗湧的黑濤中，為迷茫的航行者帶來一絲慰藉和安穩，就讓我們一起努力吧。
創辦人的話
胡力漢：不論中國和香港，整個世界已變得模糊——我們肩負的責任更大、更要堅持對光的追尋。
李家聰：一日新聞人，一世新聞人，但願能在自由之地繼續報道，抱擁新聞自由，堅持真相，為民發聲。
梁嘉麗：《光傳媒》創刊辭是「風雨飄搖」，兩年多過去，這場風雨沒有停下來，風更大了，雨也更猛。今天之後，離散媒體進入新時代，我們將繼續堅守專業，繼續努力為大家寫下歷史初稿。真相，絕不容許被篡改。
《追新聞》：四年前我們離開香港，有種責任在海外延續記者之路。今天我們亦基於最大的公眾利益，與志同道合的同道走在一起，希望結合一把更大的聲音，繼續報道真相。
PULSE HK: Crowdfunding a New Platform for Global Hongkongers
PULSE HK is a brand new international news platform for Hongkongers. It is founded by two overseas Hong Kong media outlets — The Chaser News (UK) and Photon Media (Taiwan) — together with Wu Lik-hon (former Director of RFA’s Cantonese Service and former Head of i-Cable News’ China Desk) and Edward Li (former Head of Multimedia News at Apple Daily).
With planned bureaux in Taiwan, the UK, and North America, PULSE HK will provide 24/7 news for Hongkongers around the world.
Why Crowdfund?
PULSE HK belongs to the people. We are committed to reporting the news fairly, professionally, and without fear or favour — giving voice to Hongkongers wherever they are.
But we do not have wealthy backers or secret sponsors behind us. If this platform is to become a beacon in the dark, it must be built by you, with you.
How Will the Funds Be Used?
We plan to assemble a professional news team of 15–20 experienced journalists, now scattered across the globe. With our sharp instincts and deep understanding of the region, we hope to fill the news vacuum left by the invisible red lines imposed on Hong Kong’s media in recent years.
We will focus on video storytelling — producing daily 30-minute news programmes and explainer videos, as well as in-depth investigative reporting on China.
PULSE HK will also include an English-language desk, covering both local and international news with a special focus on stories that matter to Hongkongers abroad.
Why HK$4 Million?
To run a newsroom of this scale, we estimate monthly costs of at least HK$500,000. Our long-term goal is to sustain the operation through reader subscriptions, advertising, and YouTube revenue.
However, we expect it will take 6 to 8 months to reach that goal — which is why we’re crowdfunding HK$4 million as our start-up fund.
A news platform cannot thrive in isolation. It is a living organism—its survival and growth depend on collective strength and public trust. Whether this glimmer of light can grow into a beacon in the turbulent dark waters, guiding those adrift toward hope and clarity, we leave that to all of us, together, to realize.
Words from the Founders
"
Even as the world blurs, we hold the lens steady—because truth matters. And light is worth chasing, no matter where we are.." -
Wu Lik Hon
"
Once a journalist, always a journalist. I hope to keep reporting in a free land, standing firm for press freedom, truth, and the people.." -
Edward Li
"
Photon Media launched in a time of storm. Two years on, the storm has not stopped—the wind becomes fiercer, and the rain hits harder. From today, diaspora media enters a new era. We will continue to uphold professionalism and keep writing the first draft of history. The truth must never be rewritten," -
Shirley Leung Ka Lai
"
Four years ago, we left Hong Kong with a sense of duty—to continue journalism in exile. Today, in the spirit of public service, we join hands with like-minded colleagues to amplify our voice and keep reporting the truth." -
The Chaser News Team

title: Rising From the Ashes: Help Rebuild La Santísima Gourmet
description: Our family restaurant La Santísima Gourmet suffered a fire. We lost so much, but not our hope.  With your support, we will rise again, rebuild stronger, and continue serving with love. Every contribution helps us keep our dream alive and our community spirit shining.  ❤️❤️❤️

title: Help Sprig & Vine Close with Grace
description:
After an incredible journey spanning 15+ years, Sprig & Vine in New Hope, PA will be closing on October 19th 2025. Since March 2010, we’ve proudly served nearly half a million vegan meals but unfortunately despite our best efforts, we have reached a point where it’s no longer financially viable to continue. The love our customers gave us kept us here but we could only go so far before the unsustainable financial burden forced the painful decision to say goodbye. We've dug a deep hole trying to stay afloat & we can use your help in closing this chapter.
If you've had a memorable experience at Sprig & Vine, we humbly ask that you consider donating and sharing to help us close this chapter with dignity by helping cover closing costs, bills, debt, final payroll & additional funds to support staff during this transition.
Closing a business can be costly and we would love to end this chapter by being able to pay our suppliers, employees, credit cards and debt.
Your support will help provide stability for the future, ease our burden as we move forward and allow us to proceed with dignity and grace. Any donation amount will make a profound impact and is greatly appreciated.
Thank you for being a part of our journey.
With love & gratitude,
Ross
labels: Font, Advertising, Banner, Sign, Natural foods

title: Unicorn Staff Fire Relief Fund
description:
July 30th marked a turning point in the Seattle nightlife scene. A small electrical fire at Post Options, next door to Unicorn, has caused pain and heartache across our community. Thankfully, no one was injured, but the staff’s lives and livelihoods were suddenly put on hold.
The business is working to recover, but Unicorn remains closed as we restore the space. While the doors may be shut, the world continues to move forward, leaving so many without work. Drag artists, bartenders, security, kitchen staff, and management are all in limbo as the wait continues.
As a community, we are coming together to support those who’ve brought us endless joy, through pinball, that very specific crane game, countless nights of entertainment, and above all, a loving and wonderful staff.
Every dollar goes directly to supporting Unicorn’s incredible staff, our artists, bartenders, security, kitchen crew, and management—while they wait to return to the stage and the community they love. Thank you for helping us take care of them.
labels: Facial hair, Beard, Muscle, Moustache, Active Shirt

title: Move or Die: Save Blue Ocean
description:
Hey everyone,
Ben here, and I want to share something really personal and important about Blue Ocean and our journey. For those of you who’ve been following us, you know we’ve poured our hearts into this restaurant for years. We’ve served up countless bowls of ramen, celebrated with you over sushi, music, events, and built a great community right here in St. Louis.
But now we’re at a turning point. You might have heard some of the rumblings: the building owners are pushing us out to make room for a new tenant. They want us gone in 30 days—an impossible timeline for a small business like ours. And the truth is, we just don’t have the funds on hand to secure a new lease, especially with all the upfront costs.
We’ve always been the underdogs, and we’ve overcome a lot—from surviving the tough years after COVID to keeping Blue Ocean alive and thriving. But this time, we need a little help from our friends, family, and the incredible community that’s supported us all along. We’re launching a GoFundMe to raise the funds we need to secure a new space and keep Blue Ocean’s legacy alive.
So, if Blue Ocean has ever given you a great meal, a memorable night, or just a warm place to gather, we’d be so grateful for your support. Every little bit helps, and even just sharing our story means the world to us.
Thank you for being part of our family. Let’s keep Blue Ocean sailing.
With love and gratitude,
Ben and the Blue Ocean Team
labels: Food, Restaurant, Bar, Drinking establishment, Comfort food

title: Support the Juicy Kitchen Team during Fire Repairs
description: On the evening of Wednesday, September 17, a merchandiser freezer malfunctioned and caught fire at Juicy Kitchen. Most importantly, everyone made it out of the cafe safely. Our wholesale team was in at the time and noticed when the freezer caught fire. They acted quickly with a fire extinguisher until the Ann Arbor Fire Department came to clear out the rest of the fire and smoke. We are so grateful that everyone is safe and for the quick action taken by both our staff and the fire department. While we are lucky the fire was quickly put out and did not spread further, we are still unfortunately left with extensive damage that will take time to repair. To give an idea: everything in the cafe must be removed and professionally sanitized and cleaned, the wall the freezer was against will need to be torn down and rebuilt, ceiling tiles, insulation, and equipment will have to be replaced due to smoke damage, along with an almost total loss of inventory. We don’t know how long exactly this will all take or whether or not our insurance will be able to cover all of the associated costs. The road ahead of us is a bit uncertain, but there are two things we are absolutely sure of: we will get back to serving the community we love so dearly just as quickly as we can and we will do everything in our power to support and retain our amazing team during this time - they are what makes Juicy Kitchen the special place that it is. While this situation has been incredibly stressful and heartbreaking, we have been so touched by all the love and support we have received from our community. So many people have asked what they can do to help, and our biggest concern is making sure our staff is taken care of. We are humbly asking for donations to support our team while we are closed for repairs. They are so special and work so hard to nurture our beloved guests with their food and service - we can’t imagine reopening without them. Thank you so much for your kindness and support, we love you and are eagerly waiting for the day we can welcome you back into the cafe!
labels: Interior design, Restaurant, Shelf, Chair, Restaurant menu

title: Help El Ranchito Rebuild
description:
Starting this is something we hesitated to do— But I want to take some of the load of my parents shoulders while they’re busy renovating after the flood that occurred the night of Friday September 26th, 2025
My parents began this dream in 1999 and have been welcomed with open arms from this amazing community ever since!
I grew up in this restaurant, My school bus would drop me off in front & my mom would meet the bus driver with a burro for her drive home.
I sat and did homework at the booth closest to the kitchen, and once I was able to bus tables I did, and then waitressed.
Once I became a mom I took a step back from waitressing, But remaining very much involved..So I as well as my brother & sister, have had a front row seat at my parents blood, sweat & tears go into this business for 26 years!
Walking into the restaurant Saturday morning felt like a bad dream, seeing all of their love & work underwater—
But in order to open our doors & have our work family back to work, We have decided to start the Go Fundme to help with the costs of replacing nearly every single thing inside the restaurant..
While we wait to hear back from insurance, As most did not have flood insurance due to cost.. or if we get federal funding.. It could take months, and we don’t want to do that to you, and our work family.
we appreciate you all SO much, and have appreciated the support & those who have volunteered to help..❤️‍
Thank you,
Frank, Yesenia & Berenise
labels: Logo, Awning

title: Help the Quezada Family Rebuild After Arson
description:
My name is Abby Quezada, recently our family was devastated by an act of arson that destroyed my husband’s concrete trucks — the business he relied on to support us and our five children.
We hate to reach out, but this has truly been a humbling experience. At first, we were focused on simply making it through the shock, but we are slowly realizing the deep effect this has taken on our finances.
Why We’re Asking for Help
Any little bit helps to get us by and begin to rebuild.
⸻
From Our Family to Yours
We are deeply grateful for your kindness, your prayers, and your support during this very difficult season.
— The Quezada Family

title: Keep Hubba Hubba Open & Safe; A Boston Tradition Since 1978
description:
Hubba Hubba needs your help. We, like most other small businesses, have been hit hard by recent market conditions (city structure changes, tariffs, rising costs, and surprisingly, climate change). We are in arrears for August and September rent, owe a “surprise” tax bill from 2023 due at the end of September, and need to make emergency repairs due to ongoing water damage from a changing water table to make our space safe for the remainder of our lease.
When I walked out of my marriage from a world-class cancer researcher around this time 10 years ago, I couldn’t have imagined that I would have the opportunity to give back not only the immense scientific knowledge I had picked up from 20+ years of hanging out in research labs but from living with a narcissistic, emotional (and physical) abuser. I took my half of the proceeds from our co-owned house and bought Hubba after the previous owner passed so that this iconic store could live on.
Since then, I have sunk all my savings, my retirement, and often go without paychecks to keep the business running. My family has contributed all they can. I have maxed out my credit cards and taken high-interest loans to keep the business afloat through Covid and beyond. I have made many mistakes along the way, but I have tried to learn and grow as a person. I truly believe that we are finally finding our groove.
For the past couple of years, we have operated at a loss, and I have filled in those gaps but we are on the precipice of real prospects for growth and success despite the current state of the world.
We have the greatest staff. We have weekly trainings, meetings, and brainstorming sessions. We try to listen to our customers and be nimble in our product selection to meet the needs of our community. We really want to expand. There are real opportunities and importance for a store like ours in today’s climate. Massachusetts is poised to become a haven for the LGBTQ+ community (especially for trans individuals) and as laws change across the country, access to sexual health products and information is becoming very limited. Access to fashion and accessories from other countries is also becoming prohibitively expensive to obtain on an individual level. We have always tried to bring in the best products at value-driven prices.
Our ask
: we want to make our existing space safe for the remaining length of our lease (4 years).
We want to grow, do more with the community, and expand!
We want to celebrate 50 years in business (in 2028!)
We are currently working on exciting collaborations!
We are starting an online educational newsletter! (
sign up here
)
We are starting an online education program!
The construction in our area in the fall of 2023 (city replacement of pipes, resealing of the driveway behind the building, and other local construction projects), changed the water table in our area so that water began seeping through the walls into our below grade space. We have fought the good fight in keeping the space “safe,” running three HEPA filters constantly, constantly cleaning, bringing in the Health Department, running mold tests, etc. but it has taken a toll on the health and welfare of me and my employees. The landlord is finally “fixing” the leaking walls. (
Please note: The store may be under construction in late September for a week.
) However, we also need to repair the floor that was improperly installed and has been subjected to 10 years of water damage from various floods, as well as repair damaged walls, fixtures, and other major/minor repairs. Ideally, this will happen at the same time as the water mitigation repair to minimize any interruption to store operations.
Our big ask
: we also have the opportunity to take on additional space to expand the store but that takes real money… We have been storing our back stock in a off-site storage space in Everett (lowest cost), but if we would expand into the empty storage space available to us, we could expand our social media presence (including more online classes, podcasts, webinars), process inventory off the sales floor, and have more product available, including our own branded products. We would also increase the size of our currant sales floor! Which begs the question, what would you like to see more of?!
Level I Ask: Immediate Needs
Rent: August/September $14,000
Tax Bill: $3,000
New Floor/Repairs: $6,000
Level II Big Ask: Help Hubba Expand
Rental for new space: $20,000
Construction: $10,000
Initial new inventory: $30,000
Why should I give money to a “sex store?”
First off, we are not a “sex store.” We are, and have always been, an alternative store that also sells sexual health products, just like many mainstream stores like Target, CVS, or many department stores; except we are knowledgeable (and opinionated) and care about you and what you put on and in your body. Second, if you don’t support choice, you won’t have choice. Soon, your only option for buying products will be monopolies who will control what you see and what price you pay.
Popular misconceptions about the store are that we are not needed unless you are kinky; or until your relationship is on the rocks, are single, or enter menopause or have any other health condition, or a loved one is LGBTQ; or any myriad of reasons that people enter the store with real questions and real issues that they either haven’t gotten sufficient answers from the medical community or don’t feel comfortable discussing. But the truth is we are here for everyone. Everyday. Welcoming and accepting. Sometimes just to answer a question. Sometimes with sizes others don’t carry. Or styles not available anywhere else. Sometimes, we are just the only place left in the city.
Now, more than ever, our mission is vital. We are one of the last stores of our ilk standing, and unique in our mix, the communities we serve, and our ability to evolve.
Hubba Hubba’s Mission Statement:
Hubba Hubba strives to serve the local and alternative populations as they grow and evolve; with kit, education, and community resources.
If you can’t give, that’s ok! Thanks for reading! There are other ways to help:
Purchase a gift card in store
Purchase on the
Hubba Hubba website
Shop in store (Mon-Thur 12-7pm, Fri-Sat 12-9pm, and Sun 1-6pm)
Forward this GoFundMe!
labels: Pink

title: Support True Nature's Yoga Sanctuary
description:
Dear Friends,
We are planting the seeds of something beautiful—a yoga studio that is more than just a place to practice. It will be a sanctuary where people can come home to themselves, rest in stillness, and reconnect with their true nature.
In a world that moves quickly, many of us long for a space that invites us to slow down, breathe deeply, and remember who we are. This studio will be that refuge—a place of healing, community, and inner transformation.
Here’s our vision:
A warm, welcoming studio infused with calm energy.
Classes, workshops, retreats and trainings to nurture body, mind, and spirit.
Community gatherings that uplift connection, compassion, and purpose.
A sacred space where every being feels safe, seen, and supported.
To bring this vision into reality, we are seeking support.
Your donation—large or small—will help us open the doors to this sanctuary.
Funds will go directly toward creating a beautiful, clean studio space for our community to thrive. A lease has been signed and the space needs a lot of love to get it ready - Demolition of 6 walls, new ceiling, fresh paint, flooring, lighting, props, signage, etc...
How you can support:
Make a donation to help us open our doors.
Share this vision with friends who believe in the power of yoga and community.
Hold the intention with us that this space will blossom into a haven of peace.
Together, we can create something really special.
With hope in my heart and deep gratitude,
Danielle Fowler
labels: Flooring, Wall, Floor, Wood, Interior design

title: Help Build the Barn - the New Heart of Red Fire Farm!
description:
Dear Friends,
We want to invite you to be part of the building of our new barn! Our farm has always been about feeding the community, and now we have a chance to build something together that will be the heart of the farm for the future. Each of you, who are part of our farm, can be part of the barn.
We have continued farming since experiencing the worst event in our 25 year history. On February 17, 2024, a fire burned down our 100-year old historic barn. This barn was the center of our farm’s infrastructure, housed our farm store and served as the distribution center for the harvest. Bottom line - we lost our space to sell and distribute organic fresh produce for thousands of people.
We have good news to share! We’ve put all the beautiful generous donations and help from the community to work to keep our farm store open in its temporary spot the last 18 months, and we are now ready to move forward in the building of our new barn for the future of the farm. We wouldn’t be here farming today without you!
We have hired a general contractor, the plans are approved, and the foundation for the new barn has been poured. But the total cost for the building will be $1,200,000!! Even with landing a state grant, the small amount of insurance, and investing all of our available funds, we are looking at a shortfall of over $400,000 due to increased building costs. We hope to raise $200,000 of that. Without the barn, the farm cannot be financially sustainable. And we know, without the community, we can’t build the barn.
*** Breaking news - we have already raised over $25K towards the $200K goal, thanks to early supporters!
We are a living example of what it takes to feed people locally and regionally. Against all odds we have managed to do this. We farm against a backdrop of climate change in a broken system that rewards big corporate farms who use harmful chemicals, and are located thousands of miles away from our community. Our farming uses organic techniques that maintain and improve soil health for the future, and avoid use of herbicides and genetically engineered seeds. We provide jobs to over 80 people and provide the most nutritious food to everyone, regardless of income, whenever possible, by offering a sliding scale farm share, participating in government food relief programs, and donating, annually, over fifty thousand of pounds of produce to food banks, pantries, and soup kitchens.
Although the smart financial move for our family in the aftermath of the fire would have been to close down Red Fire Farm, we haven’t. We are not giving up now - because you have shown that you believe, like us, that growing healthy, local food is vital and needed.
Yes, the new store barn building is a short-term financial drain due to the huge construction costs . But it is the only clear path to the future sustainability of the farm. It will strengthen on-farm sales, allowing us to use more of the farm's harvest on-site instead of trucking to wholesale markets that pay less.
The new store barn will be located at 34 Carver Street in Granby on 25 acres of crop land  in western Mass. People visiting the farm will now be able to walk out to pick-your-own fields and picnic tables. Visiting the farm will be safer and easier, especially for families, as parking will be separate from our farm equipment. And the new farm store barn will have heat in the winter (and bathrooms)! We will have room for a full line of local and regional healthy foods in addition to Red Fire Farm produce, plus space for a small kitchen so we can serve foods made from our produce and ingredients from other local farms.
It has been our life’s work to grow healthy food for thousands of people in our community, but we can’t do it without your help. Please make it possible for the farm to continue into the future.
Thank you, from all of our hearts,
Red Fire Farm owners and farmers, Ryan & Sarah Voiland, and all the Red Fire crew.
Farm office mailing address for check donations:
Red Fire Farm
184 Meadow Road
Montague MA
01351

title: Reopen The Fridge Art Gallery: (Same Location. New Era.)
description:
We’re Going Back
The Fridge is coming home to the original spot behind Eastern Market where it all began.
Since 2009, The Fridge has been a beloved underground gallery, helping launch the careers of over 1,000 professional artists and a gathering space for those often left out of the traditional art world: graffiti writers, outsider artists, poets, MCs, queer and trans creatives, returning citizens, and youth with something to say and nowhere to say it.
We’re continuing our support of:
• Black, Brown, Asian, and Native voices!
• LGBTQ+ and nonbinary creators
• Street art, hip-hop, poetry, and raw self-expression
• Zero gatekeeping. No degree or gallery resume required
But in 2023, we lost our space. Rising property taxes, a real estate scam, and a legal battle we didn’t ask for knocked us out. We won in court but still had to close our doors.
Now we’re going back to where it all started and reopening stronger than ever.
Our Goal: $50,000 by October 1st
We’re reclaiming the original location and relaunching by New Year’s 2026. Your donation helps make it happen.
Item	                              Cost
Property taxes	$12,000
Renovations & paint	$5,000
Repairs & gallery setup	$7,000
Utilities & insurance	$10,000
Permits & licensing	$2,000
Marketing & outreach	$2,000
Artist stipends (opening show)	$10,000
Total	$50,000
Why This Matters
The Fridge was never just about art. It was about belonging.
Every donation helps reopen a space where:
• Kids can be free to create and be heard
• Queer artists can show their truth without censorship
• Graffiti is celebrated, not criminalized... And on gallery walls!
• People feel seen, no matter where they’re from or what they’ve been through
We’re not starting over. We’re picking up where we left off, in the same location, with the same mission, and an even bigger vision for what DC can be. Just wait until you meet our new community partners!
No raffles, sweepstakes, giveaways, or returns on investment are offered in exchange for any donations made to this GoFundMe.
️ See Why It Matters
PBS Mini-Doc on The Fridge (WETA)
Garfield Park Mural Project
Graffiti Doc feat Mr Brainwash mural
MAKE SPACE
✊ ✊✊✊Let’s Bring It Back
We’ve been the underdog space with the big heart. The one with paint on the walls and all of the cool kids and nerds in one space. The one where everyone had a place.
Now we need you.
Donate whatever feels right.
Tell your people.
Help us bring The Fridge back.
A Full-Circle Moment
What makes this comeback even more powerful is what comes next.
Shaymar Higgs
, founder and executive director of
The SPACE
, began his creative journey through a pop-up show co-sponsored by The Fridge in 2009. As a young artist with hand-sewing skills, he was invited to intern at The Fridge. That opportunity helped launch a lifelong commitment to creativity, access, and community care.
During his time at The Fridge, Shaymar also helped bring in several nonprofit organizations and built community-based programming for local high school students. That kind of work helped expand The Fridge’s reach and rooted it even deeper in the neighborhood it served.
Years later, Shaymar launched The SPACE as a pop-up of his own. Just like The Fridge, it grew into something bigger. Today, The SPACE is a thriving community hub that offers free classes in 3D printing, digital design, mental health and wellness, entrepreneurship, and more.
Now, these two stories come full circle.
The Fridge will reopen the gallery in its original Eastern Market location and expand its offerings to include:
• Free creative workshops for youth and adults
• 3D printing, laser engraving, and digital design labs
• Entrepreneurship and workforce development programs
• Mental health-centered art and healing practices
This isn’t just a gallery reopening. It’s a return to the community that sparked it all, and a chance to bring even more resources, creativity, and connection to our friends and neighbors in Washington, DC.
Students from The University of Maryland created this mini-doc:
MAKE SPACE
that highlights The SPACE and features Alex Goldstein!
Thank you for believing in art, community, and providing third spaces for all.
– The Fridge Fam
Quotes From Our People:
“When we talk about keeping DC weird, the Fridge is the real thing. It’s one of our last independent art spaces still standing, holding the line for experimentation, risk, and community. I’ve spent the past year writing a book about building a permanent space like this—and I can tell you, it doesn’t happen without people stepping up. If the Fridge has ever surprised you, moved you, or just made you feel like you belonged, now is the time to show up and support it.”
Julianne Brienza, founder of DC Fringe Festival

title: Quick Bite, Lincoln Square Needs Support
description:
Quick Bite, a local favorite in Lincoln Square, was hit by a reckless driver on Friday, October 3, 2025.
Quick Bite is a family owned business, started by Tom and Pete Athanasakos nearly 36 years ago in 1990.
This fundraiser is on behalf of Tom, Pete, and Angie in order to help pay for anything that they need in the rebuild and lost business from this awful incident.
All proceeds will go directly to the family and assist with the expenses.

title: Donate to Keep The Blue Lagoon Pet Store Alive
description:
Hello everyone, my name is Barb. I have known Jeff, the owner of
The Blue Lagoon Pet Store
, and his mother Pat, for around 2 years.
Jeff’s parents opened the Blue Lagoon Pet Shop in the early '80s. His idea was to reopen the store in his parents' honor. Very unfortunately, Jeff lost his father in August of 2024. We all felt the sadness of this loss and the gratefulness Jeff expresses to everyone video after video. He’s most famous for his FISH FRIDAY videos.
In these 2 years, Jeff and Pat have been the kindest and most helpful people. I know there are so many people who have also been touched by their kindness and helpfulness. As a local business, they don’t have the same amount of volume as a box store like PetSmart or Petco. I’ve watched them help dozens of people from starting their tanks, tank maintenance, fish and reptile rescue, and more.
Due to unforeseen circumstances, they need a little help from all of us.
Any and all donations will be greatly appreciated.
Thank you.
labels: Fish, Graphics, Graphic design

title: Help Andi Pay Brunch Broth and Bloom Staff
description:
Hi friends,
This is hard for me to write, but I need help.
Brunch Broth and Bloom was more than a restaurant it was my dream and a place built on love and community. From the Giving Wall to the homemade meals, I wanted it to be a place that made a difference.
Sadly, I was forced to close earlier than I planned. Because of that, I wasn’t able to bring in enough to cover payroll for my staff. They showed up every day, gave their best, and supported me through everything. They deserve to be paid for their work and making that happen is all I care about right now.
I owe $4,000 in wages. Every single dollar raised will go directly to the employees who worked so hard to make Brunch Broth and Bloom what it was. If there's anything over it will go to other vendors I owe.
I know times are hard for everyone, but if you can help me take care of them, I would be forever grateful. Even if you can’t give, sharing this would mean the world.
Thank you for believing in us and helping me do right by my team.
With love,
Andi

title: Support Moreland Theater's Century-Long Legacy
description:
Moreland Theater Marquee Restoration Fun
Celebrating 100 Years of Community & Cinema
For nearly a century, the Moreland Theater has been a proud landmark at the heart of Sellwood. Built in 1925, it is one of the last remaining single-screen theaters in the Portland area—and one of the few still independently owned and operated since 1973. Generations of families have gathered here to laugh, cry, and celebrate the magic of film together.
As we approach our 100-year milestone, we want to ensure the Moreland continues to shine for the next century. Over the years, we’ve made important upgrades—like converting from film to digital and installing new seats to keep your experience comfortable and modern. Now, it’s time to restore the face of the building and bring new life to our community treasure.
Our Vision
The centerpiece of this project is the restoration of our iconic Moreland Theater marquee—the most recognizable feature of our building. We want it to shine bright once again as a symbol of pride for our community. Along with the marquee, we have additional goals:
Fresh paint inside and out (including the auditorium’s soaring ceiling)
Updated electrical systems for safety and efficiency
A new main-floor bathroom for accessibility
Improvements to the stage and screen, allowing us to host live performances like music, comedy, and plays
A refreshed snack bar to serve our guests better
Why We Need Your Help
The past few years have been especially challenging for independent theaters. The COVID-19 shutdowns, the rise of streaming, and industry-wide strikes all deeply impacted attendance. While blockbuster films like Top Gun: Maverick, Barbie, and Wicked give us hope, the road to recovery has been long and difficult.
Yet, through it all, the Moreland has endured—thanks to the loyalty and love of our community. With your support, we can preserve this historic gem and prepare it for a vibrant future.
Be Part of the Legacy
Your donation—whether big or small—makes a direct impact on preserving a landmark that has brought joy to our neighborhood for 100 years. Together, we can restore the marquee, refresh the theater, and ensure that the Moreland continues to be a place where memories are made for generations to come.
✨ Join us in keeping the Moreland Theater shining bright for the next century.
labels: Composite material, Iron, Wire, Black and white, Monochrome

title: Help the Hot Mess Crew Bounce Back
description:
Hot Mess has never just been about burgers - it’s been about heart, laughter, and building community. But after a tough year and one breakdown too many, Ol’ Messy has been sidelined.
This GoFundMe isn’t just about fixing equipment - it’s about giving the Hot Mess crew the freedom to take their next step, whatever that looks like. Maybe it’s repairing the truck, maybe it’s a brand new rig, maybe it’s finally putting down roots in a brick-and-mortar.
What we do know is that the Tri-Cities isn’t the same without Hot Mess slinging their passion on a plate.
If Hot Mess has ever made you smile, filled your belly, or made you feel like family, here’s your chance to give back and help them dream bigger.
Let’s rally together and make sure the next chapter of Hot Mess is their best one yet. ❤️
labels: Smile, Happiness, Facial expression, Facial hair, Beard

title: Help Salinas's Smoke St Restaurant Rebuild and Smoke Again!
description:
Years ago, I operated a family owned restaurant. It surely saw its struggles and was painfully hard at times. What got me through were my amazing employees and family. David Salinas, D to all of us, was there with a smile, a hug and an amazing service ethic that brought our customers back time and again.
Pride filled my heart when he and his beautiful family opened their own specialty restaurant in Globe, AZ. What burgeoned from a smoker trailer to catering business and most recently their own restaurant, is a community centered around family, joy and the most delicious smoked food creations you can imagine.
Seemingly, just as their success was peaking, Globe, Arizona experienced catastrophic flash flooding the weekend of September 26, 2025, with reports of over 3 inches of rain in one hour in some areas. Multiple businesses, homes and cars were damaged or swept away and sadly, 3 fatalities.
We are so grateful David and the Salinas family are safe.
Their beautiful restaurant needs our help. There will be much to do and many expenses to get them up and running again. They did not have flood insurance because...who expected Globe, AZ to flood? Please consider donating whatever you can to help the Salinas family smoke again!!
labels: Interior design, Ceiling, Food, Countertop, Restaurant

title: Support Perch: a community cafe needs your support
description:
Support Perch cafe and bakery!
Perch was born in 2022 out of our love for great coffee, warm baked goods, and welcoming community spaces. After experiencing layoffs and unsafe work environments during Covid, we dreamed of creating a place where people could gather safely, feel cared for, and be their authentic selves.
When we moved to Waldoboro, we carried inspiration from our favorite Portland coffee shops (shout out to Little Woodfords!) and poured it into Perch. From the very beginning, we’ve been guided by inclusive values—especially creating a queer-affirming space in rural Maine where the LGBTQIA+ community and allies can feel supported and celebrated.
Over the past three years, Perch has grown into so much more than a coffee shop. People come for espresso, warm buttery biscuits, and cinnamon rolls—but they stay for connection, love, and belonging. We’re proud to be a “third space” where folks can show up exactly as they are.
But like many small family businesses, we face daily challenges. Rising costs, a seasonal economy, inflation, and supply-chain impacts have all taken a toll. And now, our beloved espresso machine—the heart of Perch—is on her last legs. Espresso machines are built to last for decades, but after just three years of use, ours is facing irreparable damage. The water quality in coastal Maine has been a major factor, and will require the installation of some additional heavy duty water filtration to remedy the issue.
Why This Matters
Our espresso program isn’t just a menu item—it’s one of our biggest sources of revenue and a core part of the Perch experience. Without it, we face a very real financial cliff this winter.
We need your help to:
☕ Replace our espresso machine and upgrade our water filtration– ensuring we can continue to serve the high-quality drinks you love.
Sustain through winter – so we can grow our hours and days of service, meeting the community’s needs.
Secure a permanent home – to root Perch in Waldoboro for years to come.
How You Can Help
* DONATE what you can—every dollar makes a real difference.
* SHARE this fundraiser with a personal note about what Perch means to you.
* Come VISIT us! Bring a friend, grab a coffee, or look out for upcoming Perch merch.
Perch was always meant to be more than a coffee shop. It’s a space for gathering, for care, for rest and joy. It’s a space where queer folks and allies feel at home. And it’s a space we’ve built with so much love—hand in hand with all of you. We’re proud of what we’ve created here. And we’re hopeful that, with your help, we’ll get through this chapter and grow stronger on the other side. Thank you for reading. Thank you for caring. Thank you for being our community.
Thank you for helping us weather this challenge and build a thriving, inclusive community—together.
With gratitude, Lynn & Eli and the whole Perch family
labels: Graphics, Graphic design

title: Help us keep CRUSH alive
description:
Dear Dallas Community,
We're writing this message with heavy hearts and a sense of vulnerability we never expected to share.
We are Andrew and David, the creators and owners of CRUSH. For the past year, you've shown us so much love, and it's with that same love that we're reaching out to you now because we need your help.
CRUSH was born from a decade-long dream to create a true safe space—a "love letter" to this incredible city. After working as bartenders for so many years, we poured our 9 years of life savings we built together and every ounce of our energy into this project. The journey to open was filled with unexpected delays and costs, what we thought would be a quick build out took us a year to open and because of that we opened/started this venture over budget and with nothing left in our pockets. But we had faith in our vision and, more importantly, we had faith in all of you.
Your unwavering support over this past year has been everything to us. Every single visit has helped us pay our incredible staff, our amazing performers, and keep the lights on!! literally. We even sold our home this past June to keep CRUSH going, just so we could continue to provide the space we all love. Our landlord knew our situation, and we’ve been paying our rent weekly, working hard to stay on track.
This last week, however, has been one of the toughest yet. Due to some much-needed repairs and a very slow last 2 months, we weren't able to make our weekly rent payment ontop of having a check bounce on an invoice
from a prior event.
We've just received a notice that if we don't pay the full balance of over $30,000 with an additional 11,440 for rent being due again the 1st of October, we could be locked out of our space anytime our landlord feels he wants to and he’s not required to open it unless we cure our balance.
Our hearts are shattered at the thought of the lights at CRUSH going out for good. This is unbelievably hard for us to share because we’ve always wanted to be the ones giving back, not asking for help. But we've been reminded by a fellow bar owner in our community that asking for help from the people who love you is an act of strength, not weakness.
We don’t want to be another statistic, another cherished safe space lost.
More than ever, we need places where we can come together, feel accepted, and be ourselves.
Seeing your smiles, your laughter, and the beautiful community you've built within these walls is why we fought so hard to open in the first place. We can't bear the thought of losing it all.
If you’ve enjoyed our shows, our pop-ups, and the family we've built, please consider helping us keep CRUSH alive. We are swallowing our pride and asking you to click the link below to help us raise the funds we so desperately need to stay open and get caught up
on the bills and invoices we have fallen behind on.
Thank you for your love, your support, and for being the heart and soul of CRUSH.
With all our love,
Andrew and David CRUSH
labels: Hand, Human body, Undergarment, Thigh, Underpants

title: Bad Axe Theatre Rescue Fund!
description:
Save the Bad Axe Theatre – Help Keep the Movies Alive in Our Community!
Dear Friends,
Since 2020, independent theaters like ours have faced challenges we never imagined. The COVID shutdown hit us hard, and while we’ve worked tirelessly to reopen and keep serving the community, the past few years have stretched us thin.
The Bad Axe Theatre isn’t just a place to see movies—it’s where families have laughed together, where kids have felt the magic of the big screen for the first time, and where friends have shared countless memories. It’s a piece of our town’s history, and we want to make sure it’s part of our future too.
But we can’t do it alone. We’re asking for your help to raise $80,000 to cover essential operating costs and improvements that will allow us to keep the doors open. Your support will help us:
•    Keep the screens lit and the projectors rolling
•    Support our staff and community programming
•    Expand events like retro movie nights, live-streamed sports, and family matinees.
Every donation, large or small, makes a difference. Together, we can keep the Bad Axe Theatre thriving for years to come.
Thank you for being part of this story. Let’s keep the marquee glowing in Bad Axe!
With gratitude,
Mark Rolfe
Owner, Bad Axe Theatre
labels: Night, Electronic signage, Neon sign, Neon, Advertising
