title: Support Audrey Crews in Launching NeuraArt Studio
description:
**Support Audrey Crews in Launching NeuraArt Studio!**
Hello, I’m Audrey Crews, a quadriplegic artist who, at 36, has been living with my condition since a life-changing accident at 16. I’m excited to share my dream of opening NeuraArt Studio, a unique art gallery showcasing my artwork and that of other talented artists using Brain-Computer Interfaces (BCIs). This is my first time using this incredible technology to create art, and I’m passionate about bringing this innovative work to the world.
I’m raising funds to make NeuraArt Studio a reality. The money will help secure a gallery space, purchase high-quality canvas prints for sale, cover copyright and trademark costs, and build a website for online sales. My goal is to create a platform where art created through BCIs can inspire and connect people, while fostering a community of diverse artists.
By supporting this campaign, you’re helping me take a significant step toward independence and financial stability through my art. Every contribution brings NeuraArt Studio closer to reality, and I’m deeply grateful for your support. Join me in making this vision come to life—let’s create something extraordinary together!
Thank you,
Audrey Crews

title: Help the Foglios Through Unexpected Challenges
description:
We are Kaja & Phil Foglio, creators of the Girl Genius webcomic and owners of Studio Foglio. We started our company back in the early 1990s as a way to market our books, comics, and art prints.
We post new pages of Girl Genius, free for everyone to read, M/W/F on our girlgeniusonline.com website. When we have enough pages, we publish a collection. We’ve won three Hugo awards for our work on the comic!
Things have been going well for a long time, but recently we’ve had a lot of nasty and expensive surprises.
What happened? A number of unexpected medical expenses, a flooded basement, and an expensive legal fight to get our novel rights back. Diamond Comics, our main distributor who got our books into actual stores, went bankrupt and is no longer ordering anything from us. Our convention sales have changed drastically in recent years, we suspect because people would rather buy books online than carry them around a crowded con. Who can blame them? Plus, all that drama and more has slowed down our traditional “one book a year” release schedule, and our income along with it. We thought we could weather that slowdown, but we were wrong.
We have learned from this. We’re making changes to our business model, and we do have projects coming up that we know will put us back on our feet, but all that will take a while to happen. Right now, the next couple of months are looking extremely scary, and we have to find a way to get through them.
We do have a number of other places for our readers to support our work: Our books can be found on our online company store at TopatoCo, preorders for our new Cat medals are now open, and our Patreon continues to roll along! But for those who just want to donate without subscribing or ordering something, here we are on GoFundMe, and we very much appreciate it.
Any money donated here will go to keeping the lights on in the upcoming months, that is, making sure that we can keep on producing our books and art. Thank you for your support in the past, the present, and the future. It means the world.
labels: Costume, Costume design, Fictional character

title: Support Yumi in Rebuilding Standing Egg Coffee
description:
My name is Yumi, and I am the proud owner of
Standing Egg Coffee
, a small coffee shop in the Los Feliz area that I have been running for the past seven years. Over this time, Standing Egg Coffee has become more than just a place to grab coffee—it has grown into a welcoming space where I've built deep connections with my customers through great coffee, hospitality, and community.
Unfortunately, with very short notice,
my new landlord has asked us to vacate our space by the end of September.
This sudden change has left me with the difficult task of finding a new location and rebuilding the cafe that so many of you have come to love.
I am fundraising to help cover the costs of relocating and reopening Standing Egg Coffee.
These funds will go directly toward securing a new space, setting up the cafe, and ensuring that I can continue to provide the same—if not better—coffee, service, and environment that our community deserves.
Your support means the world to me, and I am deeply grateful for any contribution, big or small, to help Standing Egg Coffee start this new chapter. Thank you for being part of this journey and for believing in the little coffee shop that could.
With gratitude,
Yumi
labels: Chin, Jaw, Facial expression, Portrait, Pixie cut

title: Not Too Sweet: Help Edith's Pie Close Our Shop with Grace
description:
Dear friends, neighbors, and loyal pie lovers,
This is one of the hardest messages we've ever had to write.
After 5 incredible years of serving our community through Edith's Pie, we've come to the painful truth that our time has come. Despite our best efforts, the financial challenges have simply become too heavy to carry.
We are doing everything we can to be here through the holidays to join you for one last Thanksgiving, but
without your help now that may not be possible.
We started this shop with a simple dream: to share comfort, create a welcoming space, bring people together, make good jobs, and make damn good pie. And thanks to you, we've done that one slice at a time. Your support, stories, laughter, and love have filled our little shop with more warmth than any oven ever could.
Now, as we prepare for this difficult transition, we're asking for your help one last time—not to keep us open, but to help us land on our feet.
This GoFundMe is to raise the funds needed to cover some overwhelming expenses as we try to land the plane, pay off vendors, support our small team, and close this chapter with just a hint of dignity.
If our shop has meant something to you, if we've ever been part of your celebrations, comforted you on hard days, or simply brought a smile to your face—we'd be incredibly grateful for any support you can offer as we say goodbye.
Thank you for being part of our story. Thank you for believing in us. And thank you for loving pie.
With all our love and deepest gratitude,
Mike & Jeff,
Edith's Pie
labels: Food, Facial hair, Beard, Cap, Finger food

title: Facebook banned me from my business page.
description:
Dear friends:
I woke up on the morning of Wednesday, June 24th, to find my personal Facebook, Instagram, and business Instagram permanently disabled. The last post made on my personal and business Facebook/Instagram pages was one asking people to support my friend at a local Drag Story Time that was happening the next day. I went to sleep and awoke to the permanent ban.
I was eventually able to make contact with a person at Facebook. Facebook stated that they were unable to increase the access of the person with limited access on my page to full admin access, and that Meta does not have the capabilities to fix the issue.
Besides the page supporting my business, I would use the page's reach to help amplify the messages of local community organizations, events, and other small businesses. I was a "steward" of the platform, sharing and tagging other businesses, and also religiously ran paid Facebook ads every 2 weeks. Despite all this, my accounts were permanently suspended without warning or explanation. My account was in good standing. The only thing I received was a message stating my account was removed due to "inauthentic account integrity."
I opened this store 8 years ago. One year later, when my daughter was 4 weeks old, she and I had to return to work in my store, 6 days a week, postpartum C-section. Some summers, I brought all 3 kids to work with me.
3 years ago, when Roe v. Wade was struck down, I stopped being quiet. I was angry, and I took action to give myself purpose. The last 3 years have been a battle and struggle, with myself and the store being targeted on numerous occasions because of my outspoken defense of human rights.
I am tired, and this latest blow feels like a long line of things/people trying to stop me. I don't want to stop taking action. I don't want one less safe space for people in our community because my store is gone.
My blood, sweat, and tears are literally in this business, and I will continue to keep fighting for my store, my customers, and anyone who has been targeted for being "different." Our differences are actually what make America great.
Without being able to access my business Facebook or Instagram, I am having a difficult time marketing my business. For the last 8 years, I have been doing bi-weekly consignment live sales that generate $2-$4,000 in sales a month. Without access to my established Facebook page that has nearly 9,000 followers and a reach of 2 million, my consignment sales have plummeted to $150 per live sale. It has also had a negative effect on store sales.
I love my store, and I love my community. Besides my store and community activism, I am a mom of 3 kiddos aged 14, 13, and 7. I need my business to be able to support my children.
If you want to support my store and what I do, everything on my website www.boldandcurvy.com has FREE SHIPPING, or you can support via this GoFundMe.
All funds raised will go towards outstanding bills and rent for the store.
If you're on TikTok, here is the video I made explaining everything the week it happened -
https://www.tiktok.com/t/ZT6XwGxPF/
Stay Bold-
Andrea Poole-Sugg, Owner of Bold and Curvy Boutique
labels: Eyewear, Glasses, Vision Care, Lips, Smile

title: Save Freccia Brothers Garage
description:
Save Freccia Brothers Garage — Help Us Rebuild After a Devastating Eviction
We are Frank Freccia III, Guinevere Freccia, and Dave D’Andrea Jr, and we’re heartbroken to share that Freccia Brothers Garage, the iconic air-cooled shop on West Putnam Avenue in Greenwich, CT, has been evicted after more than 100 years of continuous operation.
What Happened
Freccia Brothers Garage has been in our family for five generations and has been serving our community for over 100 years. Frank has worked there every day since he was 10 years old, preserving the Freccia name and serving the community with honor, grit, and heart. He worked alongside the original Freccia Brothers and his father Skip.
For years, we have been embroiled in a legal family trust dispute over ownership of the building where Freccia Brothers has always been. Despite being hopeful that it would work out, unfortunately we’ve just learned that we lost the dispute and the family member who won has decided to immediately evict us.
Overwhelmingly, the majority of beneficiaries do not agree with the eviction ruling and want Freccia Brothers Garage’s legacy to remain open and alive.
Who We Are
Frank Freccia III (“Frank 3”)
The heart of the shop. Mechanic, historian, teacher, and steward of the Freccia craft. He devoted his entire life to this garage — showing up every single day with pride and purpose.
Guinevere Freccia
Guinevere launched the brand into the digital era through social media, events, and storytelling. She even introduced Lilly the Car, the beloved VW-turned-personality that brought international attention and joy to the garage’s community.
Dave D’Andrea Jr.
The skilled air‑cooled mechanic at Greenwich’s iconic Freccia Brothers Garage, where for over a decade he’s kept vintage Volkswagens—from Beetles to buses—running smoothly. A longtime family member and beloved face at “The Shop,” he’s widely regarded as one of the best in the business.
Why We Need Your Help
We need help in order to secure a new space and re-open Freccia Bros. Nearly all of our savings have been poured into a 3+ year legal battle to try and save the shop.
Every dollar you contribute goes toward helping us recover — critical expenses, securing a new space, stabilizing our future, and preserving what’s left of a century-old institution that should have never been taken away.
️Ways You Can Help
Donate — Every contribution matters, no matter the size.
Share — Tell your friends, your neighbors, and fellow car lovers.
Tag @FrecciaBrothers — Let’s rally the automotive world behind this.
From the Freccia Family
If you’ve ever walked into our garage or drove by, you know it wasn’t just about cars. It was about community, family, and doing things the right way.
We’re devastated. But we’re not giving up.
With your help, we’ll rebuild — and we’ll make sure the Freccia legacy drives on.
Thank you for standing with us.
— Frank 3, Guinevere & Dave
(and Lilly the Car)
labels: Advertising, Kit car, Classic car

title: Save Maplewood Small Business - Borchert's Meat Market
description:
Help Save Borchert’s Meat Market
S.O.S. (Save Our Store)
Hello, my name is Josie Borchert. My family’s business, Borchert's Meat Market, may soon be no more. Once Roger’s, then Richard’s, and now Borchert’s, this community store has always been family run. Even though I am a full-time teacher, I’ve spent many years working there and now help out alongside my brothers when I can. The store has become part of who we are. But more importantly, it is part of the Maplewood community and beyond.
For 10 years my parents have worked tirelessly—open to close, every day, often without taking a paycheck—just to keep Borchert’s open for the community they love. With four new housing facilities in the area, that community is growing. This economic development has given them hope for the future, but the past is proving difficult to endure. They are desperately holding on for the influx of new families to join our community.
My Mom said that one of the hardest things you can do in life is to ask for help. She was right. The Borchert family is asking for your help.
You’ve been there for my family’s past challenges: break-ins, theft, vandalism, and repairs, but right now, the store is facing its hardest challenge yet. Due to the pressures of today’s economy they are struggling to keep their property taxes current. If the property taxes are not current, the bank that holds the mortgage will pull the note. My family simply doesn’t have time to wait for the housing around us to be completed.
We are urgently seeking your help! Without your support they will have to close the store. The goal is to raise $60,000 in the next couple of months. The funds will pay off their property taxes and cover expenses to keep the store open. Your support of this fundraiser can show the bank that the community is rallying behind this small business.
Borchert’s has supported local parishes, cancer fundraisers, and Scouting America over the years. They have always supported the community, even through the global pandemic. During COVID, the store overcame supply challenges—providing essentials when many other stores were out of stock. This market is my parents’ livelihood, their passion, and their way of giving back. Without it, they would have to start all over again. I honestly believe this is where they are meant to be.
This is your family store where each and every one of you are welcomed as family when you enter through that door. We are all in this together. It may take a great number of people to help out just a little. Let’s not let another small business disappear.
Please support, pray, shop, and drop a little in the bucket.
With gratitude,
Josie Borchert
labels: Logo, Beard, Smile, Facial hair, Customer

title: Empower Preteens with "The Joy Circles Gang" Web Series
description:
I am Barbara Thomason, creator of the Joy Circles Gang and Joy Circles®. This campaign is to help launch
The Joy Circles Gang
, a weekly web series, preparing preteens for life's challenges.
Between the ages of 9 and 13, children experience rapid changes in identity, friendships, and responsibilities. They are no longer young children and not quite teenagers. This stage can feel overwhelming, and they are not always equipped with the tools they need to thrive.
Launching January 2026, with the
Joy Circles Gang App
, this mindset-driven program with its live-action series, blends entertainment and education to give kids the support they need in a format they'll enjoy.
The heart of the program is built around "Models for Life", simple strategies to help kids strengthen communication, self-management, leadership, and character skills. Parents will recognize the value of these lessons, while preteens will connect with the characters and energy of the show.
View the video to hear how I was reading contemporary fiction and realizing how important it was to highlight issues such as bullying, relationships, and socio-economic differences, and bring them to the forefront for kids of this age.
This campaign is a Team Effort, shared by Cassie, Marketing & Reading Rumble Director, and Mallory (who plays the part of Alex), and anyone else who wants to Team Up!
I can't wait for you to meet Alex, Atticus, Libby, Mia, and Mateo, our Joy Circles Gang!
It costs approximately $1,800-$2,000/month to lease the sound studio and the necessary equipment for filming. It costs about $600/month to fund the app that houses this program. Add to these expenses the insurance, music copyright fees, paying actors, crew, and marketing the program, and it is apparent why we seek backers to help launch this important work.
We are grateful for every gift. We see each dollar as an investment in youth mental health and in the future of our society.
labels: Smile, Facial expression, Happiness, Tooth, White-collar worker

title: Continuing Paul Holloway's Legacy of Love & Generosity
description:
We are heartbroken to share the passing of Paul Holloway. Paul was the most loving husband, son, brother, uncle, and friend. He was an incredible educator who championed for students and strived to bring out the best in everyone. Paul’s enthusiasm for life will leave a lasting impact to all who had the privilege of knowing him. His infectious laugh, big personality, and kind heart has forever left an indelible mark on his loved ones and his community. #lovelikepaul
We have set up the Paul Holloway Memorial Giving Fund to continue Paul’s legacy of generosity and kindness. Donations to this fund will be used to support programs and experiences that reflect and celebrate the values, passions, and spirit of Paul.
labels: Smile, Chin, Sleeve, Happiness, Skin

title: Support Lezli's dream: Lillian's Book Nook
description:
Hi! My name is Lezli, and when I'm not working my full-time job, driving my kids around, and keeping my household running with my husband, you will likely find me reading a book or listening to a book while walking my dog or baking bread and other goodies. For quite some time, I've had a desire to find an outlet for my favorite things (books, bread, and dogs) while also getting to form relationships with others who share similar interests. That's where
Lillian's Book Nook
comes in.
The vision for Lillian's Book Nook is to have a mobile bookstore, primarily selling used books and featuring select new books by local authors. It will also include baked goods from Lillian's Home (my cottage bakery business). The bookstore will travel to different businesses and events in southeast Minnesota, such as coffee shops, breweries, wineries, and maybe even dog parks.
"But your name is Lezli... why Lillian?" you may ask. Well, in college, I earned the nickname Grandmother Lillian among my group of friends. I was the first to bed, the first to rise, and the one making sure everyone was safe, cared for, and comfortable. That's the type of space I want to create with Lillian's Book Nook - a comfy space where people can stop in to escape the real world and find a new book in which to lose themselves.
My hopes for this mobile bookstore would be to purchase an RV camper and remodel it to create more space and storage for books and people.
I will also need to purchase inventory and work on some basic branding for the vehicle. I am seeking other funding options, but I am putting myself out there to see if any generous people are willing to contribute to my dream. In a world filled with far too much negativity, I want to find a way to bring more joy into people's lives. If this is a business you want to see come to southeastern Minnesota, please consider contributing. Thank you for your support!
labels: Furniture, Book, Publication, Shelf, Bookcase

title: Donate to Impossible Moon Bookshop! #HopefulInHapeville
description:
Hi, I'm Breanna J. McDaniel a born and raised Atlantan from the SWATS.
If you want the whole story read on! But if you're looking for the TLDR section, scroll to the bottom, please!
I grew up in College Park off of Old Bill Cook Road back when there was a Sizzler on Old National. I went to school at Mount Olive Elementary School when it was called just that and I graduated from Creekside High School a little ways from Union City, so the southside has always been my home.
After living what seems like a dozen different lives, I'm back living in the Tri-Cities area again working as a teacher and award-winning children's book author.
Many things have changed around the area including the unfortunate closing of our closest general bookstores.
That's where I come in with Impossible Moon Bookshop!
Impossible Moon Bookshop is a Black woman-owned general independent bookstore and community space on Hapeville's Main Street right next to the Atlanta Hartsfield Jackson Airport and smack dab in the middleish of the Tri-Cities.
If you grew up watching
Moesha
, think Andell's without the food, (because Hapeville already has tons of great restaurants!), or, if you were a fan of
One Tree Hill
, think Karen's Cafe and the events hosted there to support local artists!
It will be a key cosmos for a town that extensively supports the arts on its main street in accord with its designation as a Main Street City by the Georgia Department of Community Affairs.
The bookshop is on the main strip beside two local haunts, multiple restaurants, a yoga/Pilates studio, a coffeehouse, a pharmacy, natural food stores, a theater, and across the train tracks from the town’s post office.
I'm bringing in students for tutoring programs, volunteer opportunities for our elderly citizens, art crawls with the City of Hapeville, and anything else folks can create with us!
I look forward to being a good neighbor to the other businesses in town and a resource for people looking for community book clubs or even someone to watch Columbo reruns with them, yes there will be, "Just One More Thing" nights at the bookshop :)
I just want folks to feel comfortable in the shop's orbit and to shine with us at Impossible Moon!
This fundraiser is to help build a budget to support:
•	Books for literary inventory
•	Sidelines for the store which will come via local artisans and artists, as well as,
•	Shelving, furniture, and other items to build out and furnish the property for our opening this winter
I am #HopefulInHapeville (hashtag courtesy of Sara Luce from Charis Books & More!) that folks will think that this is as worthy an endeavor as I do and will support this GoFundMe to get this bookshop started in the Tri-Cities!
We're building a community of constellations here and everyone is critical for its success, all help is big help.
For everyone who is looking at a dream and thinking it might be impossible... please keep dreaming out loud. I'm sending you all the good vibrations and hope!
A mentor recently reminded me that this dream started ten years ago and with the help of booksellers and bookshop owners all over the world who have taught and mentored me (THANK YOU BY THE WAY!!!) I'm here and so is this little bookshop that's making its way.
Please donate if you can and please share the good word either way.
Lots of love, hope, and joy,
BJM
TLDR
I'm opening a bookshop on the southside of Atlanta and I need your help to make it happen!
Please donate below and spread the good word if you can!
BJM xx
labels: Symbol, Clip art, Graphics, Graphic design

title: Donate to Bamboo Cottage's New Home Fund
description:
Help Bamboo Cottage Buy Land & Grow Our Jamaican Food Dream!
Hello friends, family, and food lovers!
I’m Nevado Blake, the proud owner of Bamboo Cottage, a beloved Jamaican food truck serving up authentic, mouthwatering dishes made with love and tradition. Over the past 4 years, Bamboo Cottage has brought a taste of Jamaica to our community—whether it’s our flavorful jerk chicken, signature curry oxtails, fresh coconut, or sweet festival bread, our customers keep coming back for more.
Now, we have a dream:
to purchase land where we can establish a permanent home for Bamboo Cottage.
2600 Read Street Columbia SC 29204
Owning land means stability, growth, and the ability to expand our menu, host events, and create a cultural hub for Jamaican food and community. It’s a huge step that will allow us to continue sharing our passion for authentic Caribbean flavors for many years to come.
Why We Need Your Help
Purchasing land requires a significant investment that we can’t do alone. Your generous support will go directly toward:
Buying a plot of land for Bamboo Cottage’s new home
Setting up infrastructure like utilities and a proper kitchen space
Creating a welcoming spot for customers to gather and enjoy our food
Every dollar counts, and no donation is too small. Your support is more than just financial—it’s a belief in our vision and a commitment to helping keep the spirit of Jamaican culture alive in our community.
What You Get
Updates on our journey
Invites to special opening events
Lots of delicious Jamaican food when we’re settled in!
Thank you from the bottom of our hearts for being part of this journey. Together, we can make Bamboo Cottage’s dream a reality!
Please donate and share this campaign with your friends and family!
Much love and gratitude,
Nevado Blake
Owner, Bamboo Cottage Distributors LLC

title: Support the publication of Defending the Ancient Faith
description:
Hello, my name is Deacon Mihret Melaku, and ever since my discussion with the Knetchles, God has given me an opportunity and a platform to spread the beauty of Orthodoxy to people across the world. My goal is to use this calling to explain why the Orthodox faith is correct, especially to our friends in Protestantism who are wrestling with many topics like salvation, the sacraments, intercession, etc.

title: Keep DSweets Cookies Serving the Community
description: DSweets Cookies and Gifts extends love and appreciation for every customer that has supported us for so many years and now. Throughout the first half of this year my family has been faced with many challenges including my father being diagnosed with malignant brain cancer and my mother facing additional health issues. Operations within the business have sadly become limited and we are humbly seeking the support of the community to help donate towards maintaining a presence here in Springfield and avoid closing our doors. A lot has hit the family during this time, and we acknowledge and appreciate the value of our business within the community. During this time we will continue to supply our cookies to Mike and Rosie's, Buckeye Barn and Shortstop. We are hoping for a full relaunch of our customized cookies by the end of this year and will continue to provide other goods moving forward especially for holidays. Updates will be posted on our Facebook, Instagram and website. Thank you and we extend our appreciation for your understanding and support.

title: Keep Creative Spaces Alive for Youth, Teens & Families.
description:
Help Keep Kreate What U Want Alive for Our Youth & Families
Kreate What U Want is at risk of closing its doors — and I need your help.
Hi, I’m Dianne Furphy, founder of Kreate What U Want (KWUW), a creative studio and coaching practice in North Wales, PA. KWUW is more than a business — it’s a safe space where kids, teens, and parents discover coping skills, confidence, and connection through art and mindfulness.
Over the years, KWUW has supported hundreds of kids, teens, and families. I’ve witnessed youth finding their voices through art, teens learning coping skills to manage anxiety, and parents discovering new ways to connect with their children. Families often tell me KWUW is the place where they finally feel safe, seen, and supported.
My Story
As a teen, I longed for guidance and a safe space to express and process my big feelings after watching my mom take her last breath. I had very little support, and what I needed most was to be seen, heard, validated, and cared for. In those moments, art became my refuge. It gave me a way to move through the grief and trauma, to express what words couldn’t, and to begin healing. That experience is what inspired me to create Kreate What U Want, a place where kids and teens could have what I never did: a safe, creative space to work through their emotions and feel supported.
Almost four years ago, during one of the darkest seasons of my life, I faced a near-death health crisis. As I slowly mended my body, I knew I didn’t want to waste another moment. I wanted to finally live out my dream of opening a studio: to build the safe, creative space I had needed as a youth. Even on the hardest days, in pain and discomfort, I poured myself into making it real. I cleaned and painted every wall, advertised, built a client base, and watched my vision come alive piece by piece.
Kreate What U Want became more than a business, it gave me something to live for, alongside my son and his dad. It was, and still is, a dream come true: a space built from resilience, heart, and the belief that creativity and mindfulness can heal.
Community at KWUW
KWUW is more than just 1:1 sessions — it’s also a place of community. Through group workshops, classes, and creative gatherings, kids and teens have the chance to make friends, build connections, and feel like they belong. We also offer STEAM + fun and unique art classes for the homeschooling community, giving students opportunities to learn, collaborate, and explore creativity through hands-on projects. Parents find support and understanding here, too. Whether it’s sitting down for a coaching session, joining a workshop, or diving into a STEAM project, families know KWUW is a place where they are safe, supported, and never alone.
My Credentials
I’ve dedicated my life to this work. I hold a Master’s degree in Counseling & Psychology with a concentration in Art Therapy, a Bachelor’s in Psychology, and an Associate’s in Early Childhood Education. I’ve also pursued ongoing training in mindfulness and life coaching. This blend of education, professional experience, and lived experience is what shaped KWUW into a space that heals, inspires, and empowers.
What Families Are Saying
“Dianne has been wonderful with our son! We have definitely seen an improvement in his positivity and self-control since we have started sessions. His confidence and self-expression have greatly improved!”
— KWUW Parent
"A True Gift – Thank You, Dianne! Dianne has been nothing short of a miracle for our 9-year-old son, who is shy and anxious. From the very first session, she created a safe, welcoming environment where he felt seen and understood. He looks forward to every session with genuine excitement. Dianne has incredible intuition and warmth. She connects with children in a way that feels effortless. Through creative expression and gentle guidance, she has helped our son develop coping strategies that he actually uses in his everyday life. Whether it's calming techniques, confidence-building, or learning to express emotions in a healthy way, the tools he’s gained with her support are making a real, lasting impact.”
— KWUW Parent
“My teenage son suffers from anxiety, lack of confidence, and other emotional challenges that come along with being a teen in the 2020s and Asperger’s. We tried the conventional therapist who wanted to diagnose and prescribe, which truly was not a good option. We were referred to Dianne, and it has made all the difference. He has an outlet to discuss without being judged and has come to accept himself as he is. We are seeing so many milestones and achievements this year, as well as a comfort zone he has obtained in his own skin. He actually asks when his next appointment is. I highly recommend!”
— KWUW Parent
Why Your Support Matters
Right now, rising costs of rent, supplies, and operations make it difficult to keep our doors open. This campaign isn’t just about saving a business, it’s about preserving a safe, creative, and mindful community space that youth and families truly need.
Our starting goal is $10,000. This will help cover essential expenses (rent, supplies, utilities) and buy us the time we need to stabilize and keep serving families. Our stretch goal is $18,000 to secure KWUW for the next 6 months.
✨
Transparency Note
: Whether or not we reach the full goal, every dollar raised will go directly toward keeping KWUW running as long as possible: covering art supplies, youth sessions, and rent. If at some point the studio space cannot be maintained, your donations will still continue KWUW’s mission through other formats, such as virtual classes and community pop-ups.
How Your Contribution Helps
Your donation will go directly toward:
️-> Art Supplies & Materials — so kids and teens always have tools to express themselves
-> Mindfulness & Coaching Programs — to give youth coping strategies they can carry for life
-> Studio Rent & Operations — to keep KWUW open as a safe, welcoming space for families
Suggested impact levels:
$25 = provides art supplies for one youth session + a social media thank-you shout-out
$50 = sponsors a teen’s group workshop + shout-out + your name on our KWUW Gratitude Wall
$100 = funds a 1:1 coaching session for a youth in need + all of the above + a digital thank-you gift (exclusive printable mandala)
$250+ = helps cover studio rent and operations so KWUW can remain open + all of the above + special recognition in our studio & updates
(Donors may remain anonymous if preferred.)
Join the KWUW Fam
Your support is more than a donation, it’s an investment in resilience, creativity, and the next generation. Together, we can ensure that KWUW continues to be a safe space for kids, teens, and families to heal, grow, and thrive.
Thank you for believing in me, in this mission, and in the power of art and mindfulness to change lives.
In Deep Gratitude,
Dianne Furphy
Founder, Kreate What U Want
"Believe in yourself and you can Kreate What U Want."
Your generosity will never go unnoticed, every dollar will be put to good use in service of our kids, teens, and families.

title: Sabrina's Micro Bakery
description:
Three years ago, everything changed when my husband was diagnosed with Glioblastoma, an aggressive brain cancer. He has endured surgeries, radiation, and chemotherapy, and while I’m grateful every day that he is still with us, he has been unable to work. Overnight, I became the sole provider for our family — the true “breadwinner.”
Through the exhaustion of working multiple jobs, one thing became clear: my time and energy belong in something meaningful and lasting. That’s where sourdough comes in. When I bake, I feel grounded. When I share bread, I feel connected.
My goal is to turn my 30 years of sourdough experience into a dream of opening my own micro bakery, "Millie’s Bread", where every loaf will be handmade with care, using only the best ingredients. My dream is to bring families and communities together, one loaf at a time.
To make this dream a reality, I need help raising $20,000 to cover essential renovations and kitchen equipment to turn my garage into a micro bakery.  The cost for the oven alone is nearly $10,000 — more than I can manage on my own. This micro bakery is the key to turning my passion into a sustainable business, allowing me to provide for my family and give back to my community with real, nourishing food.
Your generosity- whether through a donation, sharing this campaign, or simply cheering me on-will help Millie’s Bread rise. Every loaf that leaves my oven will carry with it the love and kindness you've shown along the way.
With love and gratitude,
Sabrina Petty
labels: Smile, Chin, Happiness, Head, Eyebrow

title: El Silletero: plates and flavors that tell stories
description:
Hola a todos!!
As many of you know, I’ve been studying abroad in Uruguay this year—and it’s been everything I hoped for and more. The biggest reason? My host family. They’ve become my world and home away from home: two amazing siblings, a hilarious dad, and a powerhouse of a mom, Dary.
Today, I’m launching this GoFundMe to support Dary’s new business, El Silletero. It’s a vibrant celebration of Colombian cuisine, with her signature buñuelos (fried cheese balls that are honestly addictive) at the center. But this isn’t just about delicious food—it’s about a woman with vision, grit, and unstoppable drive.
Right now, El Silletero operates out of her home kitchen and at local ferias (street markets), where she sets up a stand and brings the flavors of Colombia to the heart of Uruguay. Her dream is to one day open a physical location—a space where people can gather, eat, and experience Colombian culture in full. I believe she’ll get there, and I want to help her take the next step.
Dary is a natural entrepreneur. She’s built businesses before, and she’s currently studying psychology at university,  taking courses in entrepreneurship, while also working in catering and raising three nearly-grown kids. Her days are packed, but her energy is contagious. She pours creativity, love, and hustle into everything she does—and El Silletero is no exception.
What makes this business even more special is the way it builds community. Through food, Dary is sharing Colombian culture in Uruguay—introducing traditions, flavors, and stories that spark connection and curiosity.
If you’re moved by her story, her hustle, or just the idea of supporting a dream that’s already changing lives (mine included), I’d be so grateful if you’d consider donating.
Gracias y un abrazo fuerte
Here is her link tree:
El Silletero
labels: Happiness, Jaw, Facial expression, Smile, Tooth

title: Keep WitchLab's Magic Alive: Donate Now
description:
WitchLab is moving!
Your friendly neighborhood Witch Store and Lounge are losing their buildings, and we need your help!
We have been served notice to leave the buildings that have been the home of WitchLab and WitchLab Lounge. The landlord has stated that they plan to pursue an eviction due to a performance at the Lounge in early August, which they deemed a breach of our lease due to a fire element. Whether they plan to follow through with the eviction or allow us to stay the remaining few months on our lease (fingers crossed for this option), the result will be the same:
WitchLab is moving!
This is good news! It’s time for a change, and we welcome it. The timing is unexpected, as we had been in lease renewal negotiations for many months and were planning on staying, but that is no longer an option. The timing is also unfortunate as the bar has only been operating for a year and a half, which the building and development of was a financial burden that we had planned on spreading out over many years, and we do not have the resources to do it again so soon.
We love being a part of the many communities that welcome us, and we just aren’t ready to pack it in. So we’re putting out the call for help!
WitchLab needs you!
Here are some ways you can offer support:
* Spread the word! Whether by sharing our social media posts, this GoFundMe, or just telling all your friends! The more eyes and ears we get on this, the easier it will be to let everyone know that we’re relocating.
* Sign up to receive updates and/or lend a hand. We have a simple sign-up sheet that will make it easier for us to communicate news as we get it and keep everyone in the loop for any volunteer opportunities. And let's not forget about the celebration once we are settled again - you’ll definitely want an invite to that!!
https://forms.gle/dQZLUzp2BPWrsx37A
* Donate a little something to our GoFundMe. Anything at all will be helpful to us to be able to cover moving and restructuring expenses, legal fees, and all the stuff we haven’t even thought about yet.
We know you still have questions, so let us try to answer some of them here:
Where’s the new location?
Excellent question. We have a building in mind that we are hoping will fit all of our needs, and that is all we can share for now. We are keeping the rest under our hats until we know more. If you sign up to receive updates, you’ll be among the first to know! To sign up for updates, go here -->
https://forms.gle/dQZLUzp2BPWrsx37A
When is this happening?
We are hopeful that the landlord will allow us to stay until the end of our lease, in which case the move would be in early November. If they decide to pursue the eviction, that timeline is less in our control.
What happens if I have an event scheduled at WitchLab during this time?
We are working on keeping as many events on the calendar as possible while doing business as usual for as long as we can. If you have an event scheduled with us and would like to discuss what this might mean, please don't hesitate to contact us.

title: The Lifeline I wish My Mom Had
description:
My name is Kohl, and I'm the founder of Project Yarrow.
This project began because of my mom. She lived through an abusive relationship, and as a little boy, I wanted nothing more than to save her. Out of that longing, Project Yarrow was born. Something simple, powerful, and within reach at all times.
For the past year and a half, I've poured everything I have into inventing a safety device designed to protect people in danger of domestic violence, sexual assault, and human trafficking. It isn't just an invention. It's a lifeline. A way to give hope back to people who feel isolated. A way to help loved ones make it safely home.
But right now,
we're at a crossroads. Unless we raise $10,000 to secure our patent, we risk losing the ability to protect Project Yarrow and put it in the hands of those who need it most.
Your support means more than money. It means giving women and families a fighting chance. It means that someone like my mom will have the protections she should have always had.
Every donation helps us take one step closer to saving lives.
Please join us in making the world a safer place.

title: Help launch the My Best Life Dog Camp and Care business
description:
We need your support to get our dream business fully launched! Will you help support me and all of these Goodest Boys and Girls in making our dream a reality?
I’m Savannah and I’ve been given the most special gift I could have ever asked for. My good friend Tami grew this incredible dog pack walking business from the ground up and when she moved to MA this Summer, she trained me to take things over and handed me the reins.
Pack walk is so much more than just a walk in the woods!! For the dogs that attend it’s The Best Day they could have while their most special humans can’t be with them. Our off-leash pack walks are a fun social way for your pup to get great exercise, as we hike, swim, romp and learn on over 100 acres of private land. These pups get to build and maintain friendships, gain confidence, learn new skills, and continue refining the skills they already have. The joy these pack walk adventures bring to the dogs that attend is undeniable. When your dog joins our pack walk adventures you can rest assured, knowing they’re living their very best lives even when you can’t be there with them.
I’m so incredibly honored to be the pack leader to these sweet pups. Everything these dogs love about pack walks; I also love about pack walks. It’s been such an incredibly huge source of joy for me throughout a very challenging time in my life. Earlier this Summer a few weeks before moving into a new apartment, and getting a divorce, I had a severe injury that required me to completely shut down my massage therapy practice for several consecutive months.
Over the last few months, a family I’m very close with has allowed me to temporarily swap cars with them twice per week so I can offer pack walks a few days a week.
Amongst all the big changes and challenges this past year has brought my way, these pack walks have helped me heal, and reconnect with the goodness this world has to offer. Leading these pups remind me to stay present, to be grateful for all the little things life has to offer, and to smile, play, and snuggle more!
In the time I’ve been able to offer part time pack walks a few things have become very clear:
1. We all want more pack walks!!! 2. I need the support of anyone willing and able to help me get this business fully launched.
Starting a business comes with significant costs, which has been hard for me to balance while needing to give my body time to heal from my injuries. While this pack walking  business may feel like all fun and games it does require a lot of things to be able to offer this safely year-round.
We are asking for
$30,000 in support
and the money will go directly into the costs associated with fully launching and expanding the My Best Life Dog Camp and Care business. The money will go towards expenses like:
*Purchasing a safe, reliable, large car to transport ten or more dogs
*Expenses associated with the car such as winter tires, fuel, gates to offer more containment and leashes in the car for dogs that need additional support in that way
*Long line leashes, land rental, poop bags (the landowners ask that we pick up after the dogs so as you can imagine we go through A LOT of poop bags!), tick spray for the summer, mushers paw for the winter, upgraded medical first aid kit, airlift for the dogs in case of injury while hiking
*Treats!!! The training we use during our pack walks is all positive reinforcement treat based training. This means we go through A LOT of high-quality treats from week to week. It’s incredibly important to not run out of treats during our walks as food helps the dogs feel safe and supported during our adventures. Treats also help to keep the pack close together, which is incredibly important in case of an emergency while on the trails.
Please consider donating whatever you’re able to help support me and all these beautiful dogs in living our very best lives.
If you haven’t seen pictures/videos of our adventures yet I encourage you to follow along on our Instagram page. You can find us at mybestlife_dogpack This page is another way these beautiful pups spread their joy out further into the world. Even if you don’t live close enough for your pup to join, you can still enjoy the happiness of their sweet little lives.
Thank you for reading this, and for donating what you can. We appreciate you!
labels: Dog, Carnivores, Recreation, Canidae, Woodland

title: Help Megan Rebuild Hot Wood Arts
description:
I’m raising money for my dear friend Megan Suttles, who lost her beloved business and art studio, Hot Wood Arts, to a fire 2 days ago. Megan built Hot Wood Arts from scratch 13 years ago in an 1860s warehouse in Red Hook, Brooklyn.  Hot Wood had 17 resident artist studios (including Megan’s) and 20 resident artists, a gallery and a performance space but it was much more than that. It was a vibrant community space where people came together to collaborate on a project, perform a concert, enjoy a show, build lasting friendships and spend time with like-minded people. Megan fostered a caring community at Hot Wood, something that is invaluable in these times.
Just last week, Megan hosted a phenomenal opening for a show by artist Simona Prives with sound art and music by Kyle Luntz and Ryan Vahey. Musicians David Nagler (As For the Future) and The Tall Pines performed sets of their fantastic original music. The opening was a memorable night of art and music, and community, something that occurred regularly at Hot Wood.
Tragically, on September 17th, a fire destroyed Hot Wood Arts and all of the art within it.  Megan puts so much energy into uplifting other people’s art and other people in general. Let’s come together and help her rebuild Hot Wood, cover the temporary loss of income, and show her that her community is here to help her rebuild.

title: Support Island Brewing Company's Legal Battle
description:
Stand with Island Brewing Company
Should one couple get to decide what’s right for an entire community? Island Brewing Company (IBC) brings people together through live music just a few hours a week—but now, it's under legal attack by a pair of wealthy part-time residents who simply don’t like it.
What’s Happening
This couple has launched a relentless campaign to shut down live music at IBC, despite overwhelming community support and a city council vote affirming the venue's right to host it. Now, they’ve escalated to a lawsuit—threatening to close down this popular local business.
They’ve called the Sheriff repeatedly (with no violations found) and are using their money and influence—from their primary home in LA—to try to silence a vibrant part of Carpinteria’s culture.
Why It Matters
IBC isn’t just a brewery, it’s a community hub run by locals, Paul and Cheryl Wright. They’re now facing steep legal costs just to keep their doors open. My wife and I have been coming here for 20+ years and we can’t stand by and risk the ruin of this invaluable community hub.
How You Can Help
Support this GoFundMe to help cover IBC’s legal defense. Let’s show that one couple’s money and status shouldn’t override an entire town’s voice.
Please share this fundraiser with your friends.
Donate whatever you can $10, $20 or more. Every little bit counts.
Defend our music. Defend our community. Defend Island Brewing Company.
https://keyt.com/news/crime/2025/09/24/carpinteria-brewery-hit-with-noise-lawsuit-over-live-music/

title: Help Rebuild Blatch's Backyard BBQ After Fire
description:
Story:
Blatch’s Backyard BBQ, our beloved Salt Lake City staple of innovative vegan barbecue, suffered a devastating fire on Wednesday, September 3, 2025, following an unexpected medical emergency involving the chef-owner, Chris Blatchford.
While lighting a fire to begin his day, Chris experienced a Type I diabetic low blood sugar episode. In a scary moment, he passed out, awakening amid flames in the adjacent garage. Miraculously, he was able to crawl to safety. Though he sustained second-degree burns to his head, chest, and arms, Chris was treated and has since been released from the hospital.
The fire spread rapidly, fueled by six propane tanks that exploded, destroying over 80% of the restaurant’s equipment and leveling the garage space. As firefighters bravely battled the blaze—saving nearby homes and vehicles—their efforts contained the fire within 20 minutes, but the physical and emotional damage was done.
Blatch’s Backyard BBQ has always meant so much more than just food. Recognized as “Best Overall BBQ” in the 2025 Best of SLC Awards and glowing in a 5‑star Google rating, the restaurant stands as a beacon of creative, compassionate cuisine in our community  ￼.
Now, more than ever, they need us. Your generous support will help rebuild the kitchen, purchase new equipment, and restore this innovative spot that brings people together (and makes us rethink vegan BBQ). Let’s help Chris, his team, and our community restaurant rise from these ashes—stronger than ever.
How you can help:
•	Donate to support equipment replacement, repairs, and rebuilding efforts
•	Share this fundraiser with friends, family, and vegan/barbecue-loving communities
•	Send well wishes to Chris and the Blatch’s team—your encouragement means the world.
Thank you for helping turn tragedy into strength, and for supporting a business that’s rewriting what barbecue can be in Salt Lake City.
labels: Emergency service, Emergency vehicle, Fire department, Emergency, Machine

title: Help Keep the BlackOut Barber Lounge Alive
description:
For nearly 5 years, the BlackOut Barber Lounge has been more than just a barbershop. It’s been a safe, communal space where people can gather, talk openly, laugh, and feel like family.
But rising costs like rent, supplies, and everyday expenses have made it increasingly harder to keep the shop going without raising haircut prices. I’ve held off on raising prices because I know how important this space is, especially during these tough economic times.
Now, I need your help.
My goal is to raise $5,000 to cover essential shop expenses and improvements so the doors can stay open, and so the community that we’ve built can continue to grow.
Your support goes directly to keeping haircut prices affordable, maintaining the shop, and ensuring we have a place where everyone continues to feel welcome.
Every contribution, no matter the size, makes a huge difference.
If this shop means to you what it means to me, I’d be more than grateful if you’d consider giving and sharing this page with others.
Thank you in advance for helping me keep this vision and this shop alive.
Hardwell

title: Friends of BaSo seek your help with fire recovery
description:
The Jo Luck Club, Friends of BaSo in the restaurant industry and foodies of Sonoma County are creating this GoFundMe for Jenny Phan and her husband, Chef Sean Quan who are co-owners of Bazaar Sonoma (affectionately known as BaSo) . BaSo opened their doors less than a year ago, offering regional Chinese cuisine. Inspired by childhood and travel memories, BaSo reflects the desire to treat Sonoma County to more innovative regional Chinese cuisine and to showcase the food Chef Sean always made for family meal, a communal occasion shared by restaurant staff before service. This past year,  a loyal following has been built in Sonoma County and BaSo has been recognized by Sonoma Magazine as "Best New Opening" and received a glowing review from the San Francisco Chronicle last week.
Imagine the flood of emotions as the community was notified that our beloved BaSo was on fire yesterday morning (Monday, September 22)! There are three tenants in the apartments above the restaurant and thankfully they are all safe and supported by the Red Cross. Our local fire districts were quick to respond and put out the fire before it reached the apartments.  What was once a place for locals to gather and share a meal, what our team called their home, vanished in a flash.
BaSo does have insurance, however this process is long. There are many tasks considering the inventory, replacement costs, investigations and insurance forms and approvals.  We want to show love to Jenny, Chef Sean and the staff  of BaSo and help them get back on their feet as soon as possible.
BaSo plans to have pop-up dinners to help support the staff and keep the spirit of BaSo, their home, alive.
In the meantime, we hope you will contribute what speaks to you in your heart and we promise to return your love as we plan our re-opening in season two.
labels: Font

title: Support peacefood: a space for kindness & vegan homecooking
description:
To Our Valued Guests and Community,
As our slowest season of the year has arrived, we are once again asking for support to keep Peacefood alive. It is our mission to not only serve quality and affordable vegan food and desserts but also to raise the collective vibration with love and compassion for all. Many vegan restaurants in New York City have not been able to survive due to inflation and soaring rent prices, and Peacefood is still at high risk of closing. While we are immensely grateful to our loyal customers for continuing to choose Peacefood, we have still been unable to keep up with rent for several months. With your support, we believe we can overcome adversity and remain one of New York’s vegan strongholds.
Our restaurant is not only a space for eating plant-based cuisine. It is a space for all to find solace and compassionate care in a world that does not always put love first. At Peacefood, it is our goal to lead with love and build a space filled with positive energy. Every guest we have welcomed is part of our family, and we hope to continue attracting more like-minded individuals during our time of need. If Peacefood has had a positive effect on your life, we ask that you please spread the word so that more people can enjoy our all-vegan menu and delightful atmosphere.
There is great power in our Peacefood community, and we are calling for everyone to contribute so that we can keep our doors open for years to come. Whether you decide to donate to our GoFundMe, dine in at either of our locations, or order online, you are making an important impact on our beloved home. All of our staff and crew are thankful for your abundant support, and we look forward to many more years of prosperity to come.
labels: Furniture, Restaurant, Chair, Food, Customer

title: Support Happy Hearts and be the village!
description:
Hello, I’m Ally Kowalczyk, the founder of Happy Hearts Playcare in Cedar Point, NC.
Happy Hearts exists today because of a shove from God. I felt called to create a safe, faith-based playcare where families, especially military families, single parents, and moms or dads who need trusted last-minute care, could find a loving village when they do not have relatives nearby.
We opened our doors on faith with very little funding, trusting that God would provide. And He has through the kindness of our community, the laughter of children in our indoor play space, and couples who came to our affordable Date Nights to strengthen their marriages.
Recently, an unexpected insurance FRAUD
left us suddenly uninsured and forced us to close temporarily. As a new small business already scraping by, this setback has pushed us loads behind financially, but we remain committed to the mission God gave us.
We are asking for $22,752.50 to help us get back on our feet and re-open quickly so we can continue serving families who rely on us:
•	$12,552.50 – secure proper business and liability insurance and pay the deposit/binder
•	$4,000 – recover lost payroll so our caring staff can stay with us
•	$2,900 – cover rent and utilities during the closure
•	$3,300 – replenish emergency fund!
Your gift, whether $10, $25, $50 or more, helps us reopen our doors and keep Happy Hearts available for parents who need safe, affordable care on short notice.
A Special Way to Support from Afar
If you do not live nearby but have family in the Cedar Point or Swansboro area, you can still bless them directly.
We offer Happy Hearts
Gift Certificates
that
never expire
and can be used toward drop-in childcare, Date Nights, or packages.
•	Grandparents can give their local kids a break and sponsor a few hours of safe, flexible care for their grandchildren.
•	Aunts, uncles, and friends can gift care hours for birthdays, holidays, or simply as an act of love.
Call to buy a gift certificate!
When you donate to this campaign, you are not only helping us reopen, you are helping us continue to be a village for the families you care about.
For Neighbors Without Kids
Even if you do not have children, your support matters. Happy Hearts is more than childcare; it is a community resource that strengthens local families, supports parents who work in essential jobs, and gives kids a safe place to belong. By helping us reopen, you are investing in the well-being of families who live and work right here in our area.
Every contribution helps us keep Happy Hearts as a safe, faith-filled space for children and a lifeline for parents who need last-minute care.
We believe God planted Happy Hearts to be a light for families who need a village. With your help, we can keep the lights on, literally, and continue that mission.
Thank you for standing with us to bring Happy Hearts Playcare back to the children and families who miss it most.
— Ally & the Happy Hearts Team
labels: Patient, Hospital, Health Care, Medical, Hospital bed

title: Help Restore Keep Time Barbershop’s Historic Window & Sign
description:
On Wednesday, September 24th, someone threw a large stone through the front window of Keep Time Barbershop. This wasn’t just any window — it was original 100-year-old glass that also carried our hand-painted shop sign, a piece of art that welcomed everyone who walked by.
Keep Time Barbershop is the definition of a small, local business. Six of us make our living inside this building, and over the years we’ve built great relationships with people from every walk of life. That’s why this loss stings so deeply.
Because of the age of the window, replacing the glass isn’t simple. The entire frame has to be rebuilt before new glass can be installed. On top of that, our custom sign — which was all hand-painted — will also need to be completely redone.
Unfortunately, insurance isn’t helping us cover this damage. After an already tough summer with several unexpected expenses, I’m not in a position to take on this financial hit alone.
Several friends and clients have encouraged me to set up a GoFundMe so the community has a way to pitch in and help. If you’re able to contribute, every dollar will go directly toward restoring the window and getting our sign repainted, so Keep Time Barbershop can look like home again.
Thank you for your support — whether it’s a donation, a share, or just kind words. It means the world to us.
labels: Font, Advertising, Logo, Graphic design, Poster

title: Help Eve Thrive in Adulthood
description:
Our daughter Eve is a wonderful 18 year old young women with Down syndrome. Eve turned 18 this year and is now moving into a new chapter of young adulthood! Despite how awesome Eve is, she will need significant support throughout her life, and as a result Ted and I have created a trust to help support her. So far we have raised $75,000 of our $100,000 goal and now, we are turning to our community to help us raise the remaining $25,000.
This trust will provide a higher quality of life for her and cover things that her limited public assistance funds will not cover. One of our biggest concerns is housing. There is a 10 year wait list for Public Housing and no guarantee of receiving it. When Eve is ready to live independently this money will help us to expand Eve's housing options.
It will also help set Eve up for when Ted and I are gone and support Becket (Eve's older brother and only sibling) as Eve’s main caretaker down the road. Please consider making a donation for a brighter future for Eve! No donation is too small. It takes a village and Thank you!
labels: Smile, Happiness, Eyebrow, Lips, Skin

title: Help Save Mohawk Place & Restore Buffalo's Music Hub
description:
Mohawk Forever: Bring Buffalo’s Stage Back to Life
Phase 1: Reopen Mohawk, Together
If you’ve ever stepped through the doors of Mohawk Place, you know the magic. It’s where strangers became friends pressed shoulder to shoulder. Where kids saw their very first show and left wanting to start bands of their own. Where legends and locals shared the same stage, night after night, leaving behind stories that became part of Buffalo’s DNA.
Mohawk Place has always been our stage—Buffalo’s stage. And right now, she’s silent.
When we took on this project, we knew it wouldn’t be easy. We’ve poured in every ounce of time, money, sweat, and heart we had—alongside an army of volunteers who carried lumber, painted walls, pulled cable, and gave their weekends so the lights might shine again. We’ve gone as far as we possibly can with the resources we have.
And the truth is: it’s not enough.
The building revealed challenges we didn’t know we’d be facing. More repairs, more code requirements, more unexpected costs than anyone could have imagined. We don’t say that with bitterness—we say it with honesty. Because despite it all, we are still here, still fighting, still believing in what Mohawk can mean for Buffalo’s future.
But to finish this job—to get the doors back open, to welcome the first wave of touring bands we already have lined up, to secure Mohawk’s future for the next 50 years—we need you.
Your support will go directly toward the essentials that make Mohawk safe, sound, and operational:
•    A new fire alarm system (required to open)
•    Electrical, plumbing, and HVAC upgrades to keep fans, artists, and staff safe
•    Stage and flooring repairs so the room can rock again
•    Hard-wired smoke and carbon monoxide detectors
•    Startup operational costs to keep the doors open and the music playing from day one
This isn’t just about fixing a building. It’s about preserving the soul of Buffalo music. It’s about ensuring there’s still a stage where the next generation of bands will cut their teeth, where lifelong friendships will be born, and where the legacy of every show that came before is honored in every note that rings out.
⸻
With Gratitude
To every volunteer who’s lifted a hammer, carried a speaker, painted a wall, or simply shown up for this cause: we see you, we thank you, and this is as much your story as it is ours.
To every person who’s about to donate: know that you’re not just giving money—you’re giving Buffalo back its heartbeat.
Let’s Do This
We are so close!
We’ve given everything we can. Now we’re asking Buffalo to meet us in this final stretch. Together, we can make sure Mohawk Place doesn’t just reopen—it thrives as a safe, sustainable, and community-driven home for music for the next 50 years and beyond.
Let’s keep the grit alive. Let’s make Mohawk Forever.
Love,
The Mohawk Music & Arts Team
labels: Window, Urban area, Facade, Neighbourhood, Town

title: 1st Time Owner roadblocked by contamination
description:
I've been a truck driver and lease operator for over a decade. I finally took the plunge and
bought my first truck
. On the very first load, my truck broke down because the fuel stopped getting to the motor. I spent two days stranded on the side of the road until I was able to get a wrecker to tow me to a shop. They got it fixed within twenty-four hours. Three days later, I broke down again. Towed to a shop again. Monday, they looked at it and found the fuel system was contaminated. I couldn’t even get two loads completed since the truck was registered. Less than 3,000 miles altogether. Today, I received a repair estimate of $20,995. I’ve already dropped all my savings into getting this truck, getting it registered, and paying tow bills and hotel stays. Now I’m waiting to see if the dealership I bought the truck from and the previous shop are going to cover any of the repairs because algae has built up from the tanks all the way into the engine.
I’m already pinched with remaining bills for the month and bills are already going to start falling behind soon.
I’m just trying to get past this massive repair so that my dream of owning a truck doesn’t end before it has really even started.
It has been really stressful these last couple of days, especially in the last week. I left the house for my first load on the 12th and haven’t been home since. I’m trying to stay positive, but every turn makes the stress increase. Any help is appreciated, though I’m not sure this is really going to work.
labels: Gadget, Headphones, Audio equipment, Electronic device, Facial hair

title: Empower Future Leaders: Fund Our Junior Achievement Program
description:
Hello, my name is Alexa Martinez and I am proud to be the first female CEO of the Jackson High School Junior Achievement program!
Over the next six months, my team and I will be building a business from the ground up as a part of our school’s entrepreneurship class. We’ll be developing a product, launching a strategic marketing campaign, and driving real sales. It’s a fast paced, hands-on journey- and a chance for us to gain real-world business experience before we even graduate high school!
Starting a business takes more than just a great idea — it requires resources, time, and a strong foundation. Your donation will go directly toward startup costs like materials, marketing tools and launch expenses.
Every donation- no matter the amount- makes a real impact. Your support brings us one step closer to building something meaningful, sustainable and community driven!
Please Note:
This is a donation-based fundraiser. By contributing, you are supporting a student-led startup and helping us gain real-world business experience — but donations do not provide any ownership, equity, or financial return. This is not an investment opportunity.
Thank you so much for supporting young entrepreneurs and helping us take our first step into the business world!

title: Buy the Bar: Hokie House
description:
Hokie House in Blacksburg, Virginia is a landmark and quintessential part of the Virginia Tech experience. This is our home and we want to stay here forever.
The only way to promise that Hokie House stays here forever is for us to buy the building. Help us work towards that lofty goal. Together, we can truly "Buy the Bar".
Oliver Marques started working at Hokie House in the late 90’s as a line cook.  After leaving for a couple years to work for the Boys and Girls Club, he returned to Hokie House as a manager in August of 2003.  At that same time, Ish joined the staff as a bartender.  While Ollie was focused more on the back of the house, Ish focused on creating a better bar.  Introducing trivia, music bingo, and darts to the Hokie House over the years.
Together, Ish and Ollie worked for seven years before taking over ownership of the Hokie House in May of 2010.  Combined, they have 45+ years of service at the Hokie House!
The best thing about all of this is that both Oliver and Ish met their wives at Hokie House.  Several other employees and customers have done the same thing over the years, and it’s that link to the community that Hokie House loves the most.  It’s the type of love that has made Hokie House a keystone piece of Blacksburg’s identity since the mid 60’s.
Restaurants like the Hokie House face all sorts of financial hurdles including cost hikes, rent surges, and expensive equipment repairs.  To try and reduce some of these costs, the Hokie House is trying to purchase the property at 322 N Main St, but they need your help.
Please consider donating to their cause so we can keep the Hokie House where it is FOREVER!
“It’s not a Hokie House, it’s a Hokie Home.”

title: Seasons Belongs In Bed Stuy — Help Us Keep It Here
description:
Seasons has been more than just a plant nursery—it’s been a sanctuary for neighbors, artists, families, and anyone who’s ever found joy in watching something grow.
For 13 years, Deborah has poured her heart into creating a space that brings life, beauty, and community to Bed-Stuy. And if you know Deborah, odds are she probably knows quite a bit about you, your family, and how you're feeling. She is truly more than just a business owner - she's a friend to anyone who will let her.
But now, Seasons is at risk of closing its doors. Losing Seasons would mean more than the loss of a store—it would mean the loss of a gathering place, a source of inspiration, and a reminder of what makes our community thrive.
Places like Seasons matter. They root us, connect us, and remind us of the power of growth even in hard times. With your help, we can keep the doors open, protect the plants and the people who love them, and ensure that Bed-Stuy doesn’t lose another independent small business to the big guys.
Every contribution—big or small—helps us keep this business alive. Thank you for standing with us to save Seasons now, we are so grateful.
labels: Smile, Garden, Vacation, Happiness, Flowerpot

title: Support Aaron's Barbershop Recovery
description:
My name is Aaron and I own Underdog Barbershop on 1832 Forest Ave in Portland Maine . Yesterday my shop was struck by a speeding vehicle leaving the shop in a state of complete disarray . In a blink the almost 5 years I’ve owned this shop was flipped upside down . Luckily all of my barbers , clients & myself were unharmed with the real damage being inflicted on the business itself. Unsure of how long it will take to get the business fully functional , I’ve made this go fund me in hopes to bridge the gap financially and get the shop back to a functional status .
The insurance will help cover the cost of rebuilding the structure, but unfortunately it doesn’t cover the cost of business we’re facing while repairs are under way.
Im hopeful we will find a temporary solution but unsure on how long until the shop is back to normal .
Everyone that’s reached out in support I love you all and thank you to anyone that has sat in our chairs.

title: Support the Wills Family: Recovering from Flood Loss
description:
On the evening of July 26th, the Wills family home and their business, FIDO, experienced a devastating flood. On Sunday, July 27th, they were hit with flooding again. They are grateful to be alive.
Major thanks to the swift action of the Fairfield County Dog Shelter, Fire Department, Lancaster Police, Dave from the Fairfield County Humane Society, their dedicated FIDO managers, staff, and selfless volunteers.
While their priority has always been the safety and wellbeing of the animals, the reality they now face is overwhelming. Their home and attached small business sustained unsalvageable damage and devastation—both emotionally and financially.
If you know the Wills family, you know they love hard, give big, and serve with all their heart.  Now, it’s our turn to support them.
Even the smallest donation can help them begin to rebuild their home and reopen their doors to the animals and people they serve so passionately.
To all the dog lovers out there—this family and their fur babies are worth rallying behind.
Our fundraising goal is currently set for $250,000.
Thank you so much for your kindness and support.

title: Help Save Park Cafe from Eviction
description:
My name is Huseyin Yelhan, and I have been running Park Cafe at 153 Manhattan Avenue on the Upper Westside since 2011. Park Cafe is more than just a small deli cafe serving coffees, smoothies, and sandwiches—it's become a part of my life and a welcoming place for so many in our neighborhood. Over the years, many customers have become regulars and friends, and the cafe has grown into a community hub where people gather and connect.
Recently, I have been facing an unexpected crisis. My brother, who helped me with the business paperwork, suffered a stroke and was hospitalized. While caring for him and managing the cafe, I was unable to renew my lease in time, despite paying all accumulated rent, including during the difficult COVID period when the business was closed. Now, my landlord is trying to evict me, and I am at risk of losing my only source of income. I have reached out to the landlord’s office multiple times to resolve the lease issue, but have not received any help. I also tried to get assistance from pro bono lawyers, but they were unable to take my case.
I am urgently seeking funds to hire a litigation lawyer who can represent me in court and help me keep Park Cafe open. The legal fees are beyond what I can manage on my own, and I am facing possible eviction by the end of this month. Your support will go directly toward covering these legal costs and giving Park Cafe a fighting chance to stay in the community. Thank you for reading my story and for any help you can provide.
labels: Food, Shopkeeper, Bakery, Customer, Fast food

title: Donate to Help Our Mission of Changing Lives Through Math
description: My name is Clay Boura and I am a self-published children's Author & Illustrator. My wife, Sheri Boura, is an educator with 20+ years of teaching experience. We both share a passion for working with kids and making a difference in their lives. This passion has led us to opening our very own Math Learning Center in Chesterfield, MI. While we both have the passion and desire and energy and motivation to make this business thrive, we are in need of some financial assistance. We have quickly learned how difficult it is to start a brand new business, especially from a financial point of view. We have 3 children and, while our family has always gotten by just fine, we have never been very "well off" in terms of our finances. Initially, we were led to believe that we had been approved for enough money to start and open our business and have some working capital to get us through to profitability. However, that was just the beginning of our crazy funding journey. That initial lender was an investment capitalist group who pre-approved us for enough funds, but then later wanted us to lie about what we were using the funds for. Sheri and I were NOT okay with that and so we parted ways with them. We were then pre-approved by 2 different and separate lenders, only to later find out that they wouldn't handle a loan as low as what we wanted ($150,000.00). We then found a lender who WOULD handle our loan amount, but they turned us down twice, saying we were not asking for the correct amount. And at that point, we did not have our business space selected yet and were unable to accurately answer their questions about how much our construction was going to be, how much our rent was going to be, how much our utilities were going to be, etc. So then we ended up finding a company who helped us get our funding through a collection of personal and business credit cards at 0% interest. However, they were only able to get us a portion of what we wanted/needed and those 0% interest rates eventually end. Since then, we have pulled out nearly all of our own personal savings and investments to pay those down and keep our business going. We have also taken out a personal loan or two and have even borrowed against Sheri's 401k. And at this point, our credit scores have taken such a huge hit from everything, that it makes it extremely difficult to get approved for any type of consolidation loan or business loan. We have exhausted nearly every type of conventional lender possible and find ourselves in an extremely difficult financial situation. Meanwhile, in the time that we have been open and working with students, Sheri and I have fallen in love with this business. We have seen first hand how much of a difference we can make in young students lives! One of the tag lines from our business is "Changing Lives Through Math" and we are literally doing that every day! So we want nothing more than to continue this amazing, rewarding work and to continue making a difference for as many students as we can. We are doing everything we can to be active in our surrounding communities and school districts in order to give back while also spreading the word about our business, but we really just need some additional financial backing and a belief in who Sheri and I are and what we are doing! This business is so much more than just a way to make money for us. We are bound and determined to make this work and to be successful and to help change the lives of as many kids in our community as possible. So any and all help would be greatly appreciated. We are looking for upwards of $100,000 to pay off all of our existing debts from starting our business and to give us a bit of working capital. Thank you so very much for your time and consideration.
